title: naturecounts design principles
text: Missing “Required fields” Missing/renamed “container” API entry points return data container, example, data/get_data -> results (holds main data) data/list_collections -> results (holds counts); request_id (holds request id) data/list_requests -> requests (holds details individual requests) “containers” change names, package break.

title: naturecounts design principles

title: Chapter 1 - Introduction
text: NatureCounts website hosted managed Birds Canada, Canada’s leading scientific non-government organization dedicated increasing understanding, appreciation conservation wild birds habitats . Birds Canada specializes citizen science long-term monitoring programs using partnership-based model. Citizen science found cost-effective way monitor bird populations across large geographic areas. Canada, 16,000 volunteers currently involved Birds Canada’s programs. Launched January 2008, NatureCounts first Canadian node Avian Knowledge Network. serves online data dissemination portal facilitate collection, management sharing biological data. NatureCounts hosts hundreds datasets, representing well 140 million occurrences birds. include virtually Birds Canada’s monitoring initiatives, Breeding Bird Atlases, eBird Canada, Marsh Monitoring Program, Nocturnal Owl Surveys, well many major initiatives Birds Canada contributes capacity (e.g., Canadian Migration Monitoring Program, HawkCount Raptor Population Index, Monarch Knowledge Network, Breeding Bird Survey, Christmas Bird Count, Project FeederWatch). can NatureCounts webportal? can explore data resources NatureCounts via interactive maps allow view distribution bird populations time year across variety different sources. can obtain visualize information long term population trends Canadian birds. can explore individual species pattern distribution species richness location via dynamically generated summary tables graphs. Finally, much observational data can downloaded personal research!

title: Chapter 3 - Understanding and Viewing Data
text: Bird Monitoring Data Exchange (BMDE) developed standardized data exchange schema promote sharing analysis avian observational data. schema core sharing standard Avian Knowledge Network.BMDE (currently version 2.0) includes 169 core fields (variables) capable capturing metrics descriptors associated bird observation. BMDE schema extended 2018, complete version now includes 265 fields (variables). Fields variables columns data set default, naturecounts package downloads data minimum set fields/columns. However, advanced applications, users may wish specify fields/columns return using field_set fields options nc_data_dl() function. help feature, see naturecounts article ‘Selecting columns fields download’.

title: Chapter 3 - Understanding and Viewing Data
text: NatureCounts hosts many datasets, representing excess 170 million occurrence records, primary focus Canadian bird monitoring data. Many datasets projects lead Birds Canada /partners. strive make data openly available possible, also need recognize needs partners funders. NatureCounts five Levels Data Access, define dataset can used. levels set individually dataset, consultation various partners data custodians involved. Level 0: restricted (archival ) Level 1: archival , metadata visible Level 2: data used visualizations Level 3: data available third parties request Level 4: data shared external portals available request Level 5: open access contributing members NatureCounts complete authority use data provided, can withhold data time party application. users NatureCounts data must clearly acknowledge contribution members making data available. dataset comes Data Sharing Policy defines various conditions data usage. can view Data Access Level collection NatureCounts Datasets page using metadata function (see akn_level): can create stand alone table metadata table using similar syntax retrieve metadata specific set collections based project_id, can index ‘collections’ dataframe.
code: collections<-meta_collections() View(collections) # Specify the project_id you want to retrieve projectID <- "insert_project_id_number"  # Subset to retrieve the relevant metadata based on project_id collection_metadata <- collections[collections$project_id == projectID, ]  # View the metadata of the collection(s) with the specified project_id if (nrow(collection_metadata) > 0) {   View(collection_metadata) } else {   print("No collection found with the specified project_id.") }

title: Chapter 3 - Understanding and Viewing Data
text: Filtering often done based geographic extent (.e., region). filter region must provide named list one following: country: country code (e.g., CA Canada) statprov: state/province code (e.g., MB Manitoba) subnational2: subnational (type 2) code (e.g., CA.MB.07 Brandon Area) iba: Important Bird Areas (IBA) code (e.g., AB001 Beaverhill Lake Alberta) bcr: Bird Conservation Regions (e.g., 2 Western Alaska) utm_squares: UTM square code (e.g., 10UFE96 grid Alberta) bbox: bounding box coordinates (e.g., c(left = -101.097223, bottom = 50.494717, right = -99.511239, top = 51.027557) box containing Riding Mountain National Park Manitoba). NatureCounts web portal handy Within Coordinates) tool help retrieve custom coordinates data query /download. search_region function may used search region name (English French) specifying ‘type’ argument. example, country; Bird Conservation Region: using nc_count() view function, helpful option filtering data region. Let’s demonstrate use function region argument examples. First, let’s limit data search Quebec: Next, let’s say want narrow search subnational level (Montreal Toronto) don’t know corresponding codes regions. Browse code list: , efficiently, search region: Great, now know codes need can view metadata using nc_count(): Similarly, function can used view metadata bounding box using latitude longitude coordinates: Another commonly used filter specific species. order filter species need get species id codes. numeric codes reflect species identity. species, can search NatureCounts repository scientific, English French name search_species() function. corresponding species id can used download data either directly saving referencing data frame: see Chapter 4 birds, can also search alphanumeric species code search_species_code() function. function, default, uses BSCDATA taxonomic authority returns species codes related search term including related subspecies. reason, considered robust method ensuring miss observations search. ’re interested particular species, recognized subspecies, can filter search: search function case insensitive: important note species subdivisions (subspecies, subpopulations, hybrids, etc.) can also recognized different codes across taxonomic authority (BSCDATA, CBC). example, BSCDATA recognizes 3 sub groups Dark-eyed junco: modify search filtering CBC code system. taxonomic authority recognizes 9 sub group hybrids Dark-eyed junco, well Guadalupe junco: can search one authority time. Note search term needs match one authority (), information returned reflects authorities combined. want subgroups, can use results = “exact” argument return exact match. additional examples advanced options available online retrieving Region Species codes.

title: Chapter 5 - Data Manipulation
text: Often observational records database needed. filtered records using nc_data_dl() filters. However, can also use dplyr::filter() function, allows us subset observations based row values. Observations selected using: Comparison operators:>, >=, <, <=, != (equal), == (equal) Logical operators: & (), | (), ! () worked examples provided naturecounts article Filtering data download get started applying filters. include: Categorical filters Numerical filters Date filters provide additional examples work . First, lets apply simple filter() subsets data based single survey month: Now lets try multiple survey months adding logical operator: can continue add complexity filter:
code: WPWI_June <- filter(WPWI_select, survey_month == 6) WPWI_JJ <- filter(WPWI_select, survey_month == 6 | survey_month == 7)  #Alternatively this can be written as: WPWI_JJ <- filter(WPWI_select, survey_month %in% c(6,7)) WPWI_multi <- filter(WPWI_select,                       survey_month %in% c(6,7) & bcr == 12 &                         survey_year >= 2010 & survey_year <= 2012)

title: Chapter 5 - Data Manipulation
text: Now selected columns need analysis demonstrate summarise data. summarise() function useful paired group_by() argument, changes unit analysis complete dataset individual groups. example, say want determine many point count stops WPWI Route. want group observations RouteIdentifier summarise number distinct SurveyAreaIdentifier entries using n_distinct() function creating new column named Nstops. However, now ’re getting complex operations, ’ll introduce use pipe %>%. Piping can used chain sequence functions, order avoid creating multiple intermediate objects can clutter Environment! allows pass (pipe) output one line input next line. Therefore, previous code can re-written : Note pipe (%>%) set lines data (WPWI_select) referred , start. two different codes achieve exact result. Back example, might also want know many routes run year. Finally, lets look see many Observations WPWI made year. Since row data represents survey point, want count number rows containing species_id = “7871” within unique year. can first removing ‘NA’ using filter function, use group_by summarise determine ‘length’ dataset (.e., number rows WPWI sightings).
code: WPWI_Route <- group_by(WPWI_select, RouteIdentifier) WPWI_Route <- summarise(WPWI_Route, Nstops = n_distinct(SurveyAreaIdentifier)) WPWI_Route <- WPWI_select %>%    group_by(RouteIdentifier) %>%    summarise(Nstops = n_distinct(SurveyAreaIdentifier))  View(WPWI_Route) WPWI_Year <- WPWI_select %>%    group_by(survey_year) %>%    summarise(Nroute = n_distinct(RouteIdentifier))  View(WPWI_Year) WPWI_Obs <- WPWI_select %>% filter (species_id != "NA") %>%    group_by(survey_year) %>%    summarise(SumObs=length(species_id))  View(WPWI_Obs)

code: AB_Atlas<-nc_data_dl(collections="ABATLAS2", region=list(iba = "AB001"), years=2005, username = "testuser", info = "tutorial example") AB_Atlas2<-nc_data_dl(collections="ABATLAS2", region=list(iba = "AB001"), years=2005, fields_set="extended", username = "testuser", info = "tutorial example") authority<-meta_species_authority() View(authority) species<-meta_species_codes() View(species) species<-species %>% filter(authority=="ABATLAS2") AB_Atlas_sp<-left_join(AB_Atlas, species, by="species_id")

text: Plotting data powerful way detect patterns make results stand . Recall Chapter 2 installed tidyverse package, included ggplot2 data visualizations. encouraged learn function reviewing Cookbook R. also recommend download copy RStudio Data Visualization cheat sheet reference document. end Chapter 5 exploring fall migration monitoring data collected Vaseux Lake Bird Observatory, British Columbia. Let’s continue using dataset plotting example download data 2015-present. First, lets apply previously acquired skills download filtered dataset zero-fill GRCA, also keep extra variables. First, interested noticeable patterns migration timing. , use add date day--year helper function, introduced end Chapter 5, add two new columns dataframe. Now can plot raw counts (y-axis) day--year (x-axis).  notice migration species highest early year diminishes time. Next, interested visually examining mean number migrant GRCA year, see noticeable changes time. First, need summarise data. , create function calculates standard error (se) deploy mutate() function helps create new variables existing ones: Now can create plot:  notice increase mean number GRCA observed last three years, compared 2015. might now wondering .
code: VLBO <- nc_data_dl(collections = "CMMN-DET-VLBO", years = c(2015, NA),                     username = "testuser", info = "tutorial example") ## Using filters: collections (CMMN-DET-VLBO); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min); start_year (2015) ## Collecting available records... ##      collection nrecords ## 1 CMMN-DET-VLBO    24373 ## Total records: 24,373 ##  ## Downloading records for each collection: ##   CMMN-DET-VLBO ##     Records 1 to 5000 / 24373 ##     Records 5001 to 10000 / 24373 ##     Records 10001 to 15000 / 24373 ##     Records 15001 to 20000 / 24373 ##     Records 20001 to 24373 / 24373 GRCA <- format_zero_fill(VLBO, species = 15900,                           by = "SamplingEventIdentifier",                           extra_event= c("survey_year", "survey_month", "survey_day")) ##  - Consider summarizing multiple observations per set of 'by' before zero-filling to increase speed ##  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric GRCA_dates <- format_dates(GRCA) ggplot(data = GRCA_dates) +    geom_point(aes(x = doy, y = ObservationCount)) #use this shortcut function to calculate the standard error se <- function(x) sd(x) / sqrt(length(x))  GRCA_year <- GRCA %>%    group_by(survey_year) %>%    summarise(MeanObs = mean(ObservationCount),              SEObs = se(ObservationCount)) %>%      mutate(yrmin = MeanObs + SEObs, yrmax = MeanObs - SEObs) ggplot(data = GRCA_year) +     geom_pointrange(aes(x = survey_year, y = MeanObs, ymin = yrmin, ymax = yrmax))

GRCA<-VLBO %>% group_by(survey_year) %>% summarize(day_distinct = n_distinct(doy)) #Could have alternatively counted the number of district `SamplingEventIdentifier`  View(GRCA) #You will pull all the data for this exercise, not just the records for Gray catbird. title: Chapter 1 - Spatial Data Exploration
text: Spatial data type vector raster data represents feature phenomena across geographic space. Vector data used represent features points, lines polygons. may include individual bird observations, rivers, conservation area boundaries. Raster data used represent spatially continuous data grid, cell one value. may include types environmental data like temperature, elevation land use. common format used store vector data file disk ESRI Shapefile format (.shp). Shapefiles always accompanied files .dbf, .shx, .prj extensions. Raster data files typically stored TIFF GeoTIFF files (.tif) (.tiff) extension. Raster data manipulation covered subsequent chapters (see Chapter 3: Climate Data, Chapter 4: Elevation Data, Chapter 5: Land Cover Data, Chapter 6: Satellite Imagery, Chapter 7: Raster Summary). Vector raster data may also associated attribute data temporal data. Attribute data provides additional information characteristics spatial features temporal data assigns specific date time range. sf package provides simple feature access R. package works best spatial data (point, line, polygon, multipolygon) associated tabular attributes (e.g shapefiles). may familiar sp package similar functionality different format, however, package longer use 2023 support integration tidyverse popular among data scientists use R.

title: Chapter 1 - Spatial Data Exploration
text: Geoprocessing functions allow us manipulate compute spatial objects based interactions geometries. several useful functions integrated sf package including: st_transform() - transforms CRS specified CRS objectst_drop_geometry() - removes geometry column sf objectst_intersection(x, y) - creates geometry shared portion x yst_crop(x, y, ..., xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax) - creates geometry x intersects specified rangest_difference(x, y) - creates geometry x intersect yst_area, st_length, st_distance can also used compute geometric measurements resources, including sf package cheatsheat can found .

what: Example 1 - You would like to visualize the spatio-temporal distribution of Cedar Waxwing observations in June of each survey year using data from the Maritimes Breeding Bird Atlas (2006-2010).
title: Chapter 1 - Spatial Data Exploration
text: Let’s fetch NatureCounts data. First, look find collection code Maritimes Breeding Bird Atlas. Second, look find numeric species id. Now can download data. data download work unless replace "testuser" actual user name. prompted enter password. Use format_dates function create date day--year (doy) columns. Filter data include observations month June. Convert NatureCounts data spatial object using point count coordinates. Finally, use ggplot2 visualize spatio-temporal distribution Cedar Waxwing observations across Maritime provinces color-coding data points survey_year creating multi-panel plot based discrete variable:  map provides simple visualization NatureCounts data broad spatial temporal scale. Congratulations! completed Chapter 1: Spatial Data Exploration. , successfully visualized NatureCounts vector data wide spatial temporal scale using multi-panel plot. Chapter 2, can explore spatial data manipulation, apply geoprocessing functions, visualize NatureCounts data within Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) Priority Places.
code: collections <- meta_collections() View(meta_collections()) search_species("cedar waxwing") #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name              english_name           french_name                    taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>                        <chr>                  <chr>                          <chr>       #> 1      16330 Bombycilla cedrorum          Cedar Waxwing          Jaseur d'Amérique              BIRDS       #> 2      40749 Bombycilla garrulus/cedrorum Bohemian/Cedar Waxwing Jaseur boréal ou J. d'Amérique BIRDS cedar_waxwing <- nc_data_dl(collections = "MBBA2PC", species = 16330,                              username = "testuser", info = "spatial_data_tutorial") #> Using filters: collections (MBBA2PC); species (16330); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min) #> Collecting available records... #>   collection nrecords #> 1    MBBA2PC     1659 #> Total records: 1,659 #>  #> Downloading records for each collection: #>   MBBA2PC #>     Records 1 to 1659 / 1659 cedar_waxwing <- format_dates(cedar_waxwing) cedar_waxwing_june <- cedar_waxwing %>%   filter(survey_month == 6) cedar_waxwing_june_sf <- st_as_sf(cedar_waxwing_june,                                   coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) ggplot(data = cedar_waxwing_june_sf) +   # Select a basemap   annotation_map_tile(type = "cartolight", zoom = NULL, progress = "none") +   # Plot the points, color-coded by survey_year   geom_sf(aes(color = as.factor(survey_year)), size = 1) +   # Facet by survey_year to create the multi-paneled map   facet_wrap(~ survey_year) +   # Customize the color scale   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1", name = "Survey Year") +   # Add a theme with a minimal design and change the font styles, to your preference   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") +   # To make the points in the legend larger without affecting map points   guides(color = guide_legend(override.aes = list(size = 3))) +   # Define the title and axis names   labs(title = "Cedar Waxwing June Observations by Survey Year",        x = "Longitude",        y = "Latitude")

what: Example 2a - You are interested in assessing the spatial distribution of Wood Ducks (Ontario Breeding Bird Atlas data) across the KBAs found within the province of Ontario.
title: Chapter 2 - Spatial Subsetting
text: Navigate KBA Canada Map Viewer filter data Ontario using left hand Province/Territory filter. select ‘Download’. want select csv shp example. can read KBA polygons using sf package working directory. downloaded files renamed example need change code match file name. sf objects stored R spatial dataframe contains attribute table vector along geometry type. examine dataframe, looks like many duplicate entries including duplicate geometries (vertices). clean , can apply st_make_valid() distinct() functions spatial dataframe: spatial data also accompanied CSV file contains additional useful attributes (landcover, species, etc) concerning KBAs. Let’s read accompanying CSV file KBA layer. Great! can now join dataframes using handy tidyverse package. However, ’ll want select specific columns first avoid redundancies performing join: dataframes now contain unique columns, selection. apply full_join() function hold attributes within one dataframe. visualize ontario_kba data can use ggplot().  can also visualize ontario_kba data interactive map, using leaflet package. Similarly, package mapview (based leaflet) can used make interactive plots. can represent specific attributes like : example, interested KBA polygons Ontario. However, working larger data set, possible filter dataframe retrieve specific polygons meet certain criteria relevant research. , can apply filters based variable condition. example, say wanted KBA’s greater 100km^2 size: execute code chunk, remove # Let’s search NatureCounts Ontario Breeding Bird Atlas point count dataset using meta_collections() Wood Duck species ID using search_species(). Now can download NatureCounts data. Remember change testuser personal username. can convert NatureCounts data spatial object. , deploy st_as_sf function specify coordinate reference system (CRS). CRS KBA sf object can returned st_crs(). KBA sf object stored World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS 84) coordinates, EPSG = 4326. Now can convert atlas_on dataframe sf object using CRS. Now let’s ensure conversion successful. ’ll notice new geometry column observation point. st_transform() function can applied project spatial object using different CRS like NAD83 / UTM zone 16N (EPSG = 26916). can also used ensure CRS spatial objects match. identify Wood Ducks observed across Ontario KBA’s, can apply st_intersection() function. get warning message, can safely ignore. Using ggplot, can visualize polygon data point data.  can also apply leaflet visualize polygon data point data, using addPolygons() addCircleMarkers() arguments. geoprocessing data, can write sf objects Shapefiles disk, argument delete_layer = TRUE used overwrite existing file. execute code chunk, remove #
code: ontario_kba <- st_read("ontario_kba.shp") ontario_kba <- ontario_kba %>% st_make_valid() %>% distinct() kba_attributes <- read.csv("ontario_kba.csv") kba_attributes <- kba_attributes %>%   select("SiteCode",          "DateAssessed",          "PercentProtected",          "BoundaryGeneralized",          "Level",          "CriteriaMet",          "ConservationActions",          "Landcover",          "Province",          "Species") ontario_kba <- full_join(ontario_kba, kba_attributes, by = "SiteCode") ggplot() +    # Select the basemap   annotation_map_tile(type = "cartolight", zoom = NULL, progress = "none") +   # Add the polygon data   geom_sf(data = ontario_kba, aes(fill = "Ontario KBAs"), color = "black",            size = 0.5, alpha = 0.5) +   # Add the map components   theme_minimal() +    scale_fill_manual(values = c("Ontario KBAs" = "red")) +    theme(legend.position = "bottom") +   labs(title = "Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) of Ontario",        x = "Longitude",        y = "Latitude",        fill = "Legend") leaflet(width = "100%") %>%   addTiles() %>%   addPolygons(data = ontario_kba, color = "black", weight = 2, smoothFactor = 1,                opacity = 1.0, fillOpacity = 0.5, fillColor = "red") %>%    addFullscreenControl() %>%   addLegend(colors = c("red"),labels = c("Ontario KBAs"), position = "bottomright") mapview(ontario_kba, zcol = "PercentProtected") # kba_name <- ontario_kba %>%    # filter(Area > 100) collections <- meta_collections() View(meta_collections()) search_species("wood duck") #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   species_id x Hooded Merganser (hybrid) Hybride Canard branchu x Harle couro… BIRDS       #> 4      45989 Aix sponsa x Mareca americana      Wood Duck x American Wigeon (hybrid)  Hybride Canard branchu x C. "OBBA2PC", species = 360,                         username = "testuser", info = "spatial_data_tutorial") st_crs(ontario_kba) #> Coordinate Reference System: #>   User input: WGS 84  #>   wkt: #>          :sfc_POINT of length 290; first list element:  'XY' num  -80.1 43.7 #>  - attr(*, "sf_column")= chr "geometry" #>  - attr(*, "agr")= Factor w/ 3 levels "constant","aggregate",..: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ... #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:55] "record_id" "collection" "project_id" "protocol_id" ... ontario_kba <- st_transform(ontario_kba, crs = 26916) atlas_on_sf <- st_transform(atlas_on_sf, crs = st_crs(ontario_kba)) wood_ducks_kba <- st_intersection(ontario_kba, atlas_on_sf) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all geometries # If need be, transform your spatial data back to EPSG:4326 to visualize with leaflet ontario_kba <- st_transform(ontario_kba, crs = 4326) wood_ducks_kba <- st_transform(wood_ducks_kba, crs = 4326) ggplot() +   # Select a basemap   annotation_map_tile(type = "osm", zoom = NULL, progress = "none") +   # Plot the filtered KBA polygon (ON001)   geom_sf(data = ontario_kba, aes(fill = "Ontario KBA"), color = "black", size = 0.5, alpha = 0.5) +   # Plot the Wood Duck observations that are within the KBA   geom_sf(data = wood_ducks_kba, aes(color = "Wood Duck Observations"), size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +   # Custom fill and color for the legend   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Ontario KBA" = "violet"), name = "Legend") +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Wood Duck Observations" = "orange"), name = "Legend") +   # Automatically zoom to the extent of the ON001 polygon   coord_sf() +   # Map components   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottomright") +   labs(title = "Key Biodiversity Area (KBA) - Long Point Peninsula and Marshes",        x = "Longitude",        y = "Latitude") leaflet(width = "100%") %>%   addTiles() %>%   addPolygons(data = ontario_kba, color = "black", weight = 2, smoothFactor = 1,                opacity = 1.0, fillOpacity = 0.5, fillColor = "violet") %>%   addCircleMarkers(data = wood_ducks_kba, radius = 3, color = "orange",                     stroke = FALSE, fillOpacity = 0.8) %>%   addFullscreenControl() %>%   addLegend(colors = c("violet", "orange"),              labels = c("Ontario KBA", "Wood Duck Observations"),              position = "bottomright") # st_write(wood_ducks_kba,"wood_ducks_kba.shp", driver = "ESRI Shapefile", delete_layer = TRUE)

what: Example 2b - You want to assess the spatial distribution of Wood Ducks (Ontario Breeding Bird Atlas data) across the Long Point Walsingham Forest Priority Place.
title: Chapter 2 - Spatial Subsetting
text: Navigate Priority Places - Open Government Portal. Scroll Data Resources section select Priority Places file labeled English, dataset, FGDB/GDB. First, lets create path downloaded Priority Place file. , let’s inspect spatial data. read spatial data object, apply st_read function specify desired data layer. interested spatial distribution Wood Ducks across Long Point Walsingham Forest Priority Place. ’ll filter based variable condition. reproject Wood Duck data match Priority Place using st_transform. Next, ’ll apply geoprocessing function find Wood Duck observations intersect chosen Priority Place. Finally, ’ll transform spatial objects one time visualizing leaflet. Use ggplot visualize polygon point data.  can also apply leaflet visualize polygon data point data, using addPolygons() addCircleMarkers() arguments. geoprocessing data, can write sf objects Shapefiles disk, argument delete_layer = TRUE used overwrite existing file. execute code chunk, remove # Congratulations! completed Chapter 2 - Spatial Subsetting: KBA’s Priority Places. , spatially filtered visualized NatureCounts data. Chapter 3, can explore spatial data visualization linking climate data NatureCounts observations.
code: gdb_path <- "PriorityPlaces.gdb" gdb_layers <- st_layers(gdb_path) print(gdb_layers) #> Driver: OpenFileGDB  #> Available layers: #>               layer_name geometry_type features fields                     crs_name #> 1 PriorityPlacesBoundary Multi Polygon       11     11 NAD83 / Canada Atlas Lambert #> 2  PriorityPlacesProject   Multi Point       89     13 NAD83 / Canada Atlas Lambert priori_place_polygons <- st_read(dsn = gdb_path, layer = "PriorityPlacesBoundary") #> Reading layer `PriorityPlacesBoundary' from data source  #>   `/home/steffi/Projects/Business/Birds Canada/NatureCounts/naturecounts/misc/data/priority_places/priorityplaces.gdb'  #>   using driver `OpenFileGDB' #> Simple feature collection with 11 features and 11 fields #> Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -2135754 ymin: -586679 xmax: 2450963 ymax: 2554209 #> Projected CRS: NAD83 / Canada Atlas Lambert long_point_polygon <- priori_place_polygons %>%   filter(Name == "Long Point Walsingham Forest") # filters based on multipolygon name atlas_on_sf <- st_transform(atlas_on_sf, crs = st_crs(long_point_polygon)) wood_ducks_longpoint <- st_intersection(long_point_polygon, atlas_on_sf) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all geometries long_point_polygon <- st_transform(long_point_polygon, crs = 4326) wood_ducks_longpoint <- st_transform(wood_ducks_longpoint, crs = 4326) ggplot() +   # Select a basemap   annotation_map_tile(type = "cartolight", zoom = NULL, progress = "none") +   # Plot the Long Point polygon   geom_sf(data = long_point_polygon, aes(fill = "Long Point Walsingham Forest"),             color = "black", size = 0.5, alpha = 0.5) +   # Plot the Wood Duck observations   geom_sf(data = wood_ducks_longpoint, aes(color = "Wood Duck Observations"),            size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +   # Custom fill and color for the legend   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Long Point Walsingham Forest" = "red"), name = "Legend") +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Wood Duck Observations" = "green"), name = "Legend") +   # Automatically zoom to the extent of the Long Point polygon   coord_sf() +   # Map components   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottomright") +   labs(title = "Wood Duck Observations within Long Point Walsingham",        x = "Longitude",        y = "Latitude") leaflet(width = "100%") %>%   addTiles() %>%   addPolygons(data = long_point_polygon, color = "black", weight = 2,                smoothFactor = 1, opacity = 1.0, fillOpacity = 0.5, fillColor = "red") %>%   addCircleMarkers(data = wood_ducks_longpoint, radius = 5, color = "green",                     stroke = FALSE, fillOpacity = 0.8) %>%   addFullscreenControl() %>%   addLegend(colors = c("red", "green"),              labels = c("Long Point Walsingham Forest", "Wood Duck Observations"),              position = "bottomright") # st_write(wood_ducks_longpoint,"wood_ducks_longpoint.shp", driver = "ESRI Shapefile", delete_layer = TRUE)

text: download NatureCounts data, can specify collection species code relevant research. Replace testuser user name. data download work unless replace "testuser" actual user name. prompted enter password. eBird greatest number Whooping Crane records, however, collection comprise data Access Level 4. wish access collection must sign free account make data request. Otherwise, can carry forward tutorial without data skip code chunk. Grouping NatureCounts data might provide meaningful insight species occurrences site might vary across time space. can achieve summarizing species occurrence SiteCode survey year, keeping coordinate information site using group_by summarise functions: Lastly, can summarize NatureCounts data get annual total counts Whooping Cranes, say 1985 2011. , can 1) produce regular dataframe called cranes_summary dropping geometry column (st_drop_geometry) 2) calculate annual_count using summarise sum functions 3) filter NA values year:
code: collections <- meta_collections()  View(meta_collections()) search_species("whooping crane") View(search_species("whooping crane")) whooping_crane_data <- nc_data_dl(   collections = c("ABATLAS1", "ABATLAS2", "ABBIRDRECS"), species = 4030,    username = "testuser", info = "spatial_data_tutorial") whooping_crane_data <- nc_data_dl(   collections = c("ABATLAS1", "ABATLAS2", "ABBIRDRECS","EBIRD-CA-PR"), species = 4030,    username = "testuser", info = "spatial_data_tutorial") species_occurrence_summary <- whooping_crane_data %>%   format_dates() %>%    group_by(SiteCode, survey_year, longitude, latitude) %>%   summarise(total_count = sum(as.numeric(ObservationCount), na.rm = TRUE)) %>%   ungroup() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'SiteCode', 'survey_year', 'longitude'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. cranes_summary <- species_occurrence_summary %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%   group_by(survey_year) %>%   summarize(annual_count = sum(total_count, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%   filter(!is.na(survey_year)) %>%   filter(survey_year >= 1985 & survey_year <= 2011) cranes_summary #> # A tibble: 12 × 2 #>    survey_year annual_count #>          <int>        <dbl> #>  1        1987            0 #>  2        1988            0 #>  3        1989            0 #>  4        1990            0 #>  5        1991            0 #>  6        1996            1 #>  7        2000           24 #>  8        2001           14 #>  9        2002           26 #> 10        2003           14 #> 11        2004           18 #> 12        2005          180

ℹ 2 more variables: normals_1981_2010 <lgl>, normals_1971_2000 <lgl> birch_station <- stations_search(name = "BIRCH MOUNTAIN LO", interval = "day") buckton_station <- stations_search(name = "BUCKTON LO", interval = "day") wood_buff_stations <- rbind(birch_station, buckton_station) # combine weather <- weather_dl(station_ids = wood_buff_stations$station_id,                       start = "1985-01-01",                       end = "2011-12-31",                       interval = "day", quiet = TRUE) #prov_stations <- stations %>% #  filter(prov %in% c("AB"), #         interval == "day", #         start >= 1960, #         end <= 2023, #         elev < 1000) # weather <- weather_dl(station_ids = prov_stations$station_id, #                       start = "2000-01-01", #                       end = "2023-12-31", #                       interval = "day", quiet = TRUE) yearly_climate <- weather %>%   filter(month(date) %in% 5:8) %>%  # Filter for summer months May (5) through August (8)   group_by(survey_year = year(date)) %>%   # Group by year   summarize(     yearly_avg_temp = mean(mean_temp, na.rm = TRUE),     yearly_avg_precip = mean(total_precip, na.rm = TRUE)   ) yearly_climate #> # A tibble: 27 × 3 #>    survey_year yearly_avg_temp yearly_avg_precip #>          <dbl>           <dbl>             <dbl> #>  1        1985            11.6              1.14 #>  2        1986            11.7              2.96 #>  3        1987            11.8              2.71 #>  4        1988            12.1              3.40 #>  5        1989            13.0              1.85 #>  6        1990            13.1              2.44 #>  7        1991            13.4              3.40 #>  8        1992            11.2              2.40 #>  9        1993            10.7              3.00 #> 10        1994            13.2              3.39 #> # ℹ 17 more rows cranes_climate_summary <- left_join(cranes_summary, yearly_climate, by = "survey_year") cranes_climate_summary #> # A tibble: 12 × 4 #>    survey_year annual_count yearly_avg_temp yearly_avg_precip #>          <dbl>        <dbl>           <dbl>             <dbl> #>  1        1987            0            11.8              2.71 #>  2        1988            0            12.1              3.40 #>  3        1989            0            13.0              1.85 #>  4        1990            0            13.1              2.44 #>  5        1991            0            13.4              3.40 #>  6        1996            1            11.7              3.37 #>  7        2000           24            10.6              3.83 #>  8        2001           14            13.7              2.76 #>  9        2002           26            11.3              3.18 #> 10        2003           14            12.9              2.72 #> 11        2004           18            10.6              2.08 #> 12        2005          180            10.7              2.89 ggplot(cranes_climate_summary, aes(x = yearly_avg_temp, y = annual_count)) +   geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +  # Simple blue points   geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +  # Add linear regression line   theme_minimal() +   labs(x = "Avg Temperature (°C)",         y = "Total Count",         title = "Whooping Crane Count vs. Annual Avg Summer Temp") +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))  # Center the title #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ggplot(cranes_climate_summary, aes(x = yearly_avg_precip, y = annual_count)) +   geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +  # Simple blue points   geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +  # Add linear regression line   theme_minimal() +   labs(x = "Avg Precipitation",         y = "Total Count",         title = "Whooping Crane Count vs. Annual Avg Summer Precip") +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))  # Center the title #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Qu.:54.24 epsg:4326 : 0 #> Median :-113.0 Median :59.90 +proj=long...: 0 #> Mean :-112.7 Mean :57.49 #> 3rd Qu.:-111.7 3rd Qu.:59.97 #> Max. :-110.2 Max. :60.21 # Scatter plot of bird observations against a bioclimatic variable (bio1 = Annual Mean Temperature) ggplot(data = bioclim_data, aes(x = bio1, y = total_count)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.6) + labs(title = "Bird Observations vs. Bioclimatic Variable (bio1)", x = "Annual Mean Temperature", y = "ObservationCount") + theme_minimal() bioclim_data <- st_transform(bioclim_data, crs = 4326) # Group by SiteCode and summarize total_count bioclim_data <- bioclim_data %>% group_by(SiteCode) %>% summarize(total_count = sum(total_count, na.rm = TRUE), bio1 = mean(bio1, na.rm = TRUE), latitude = first(latitude), longitude = first(longitude)) # Define color palette for bio1 pal <- colorNumeric(palette = "YlOrRd", domain = bioclim_data$bio1) # Define a scaling factor for total_count scaling_factor <- 2 # Adjust this to scale the circle size # Plot using leaflet leaflet(bioclim_data) %>% addTiles() %>% addCircleMarkers( ~longitude, ~latitude, radius = ~pmin(pmax(sqrt(total_count) * scaling_factor, 3), 15), # Scale and limit radius fillColor = ~pal(bio1), # Color points by bio1 color = "black", stroke = TRUE, fillOpacity = 0.8, popup = ~paste0("SiteCode: ", SiteCode, "
", "Total Count: ", total_count, "
", "Bio1: ", bio1) # creates info popup labels ) %>% addLegend(pal = pal, values = ~bio1, title = "Bio1", position = "bottomright") %>% addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft", options = scaleBarOptions(imperial = FALSE))

La Mauricie National Park situated Laurentian mountains covers 536 km2 within Eastern Canadian Temperate-Boreal Forest transition ecoregion. environment characterized mixed forests, lakes, rivers, hills range 150 m 500 m elevation. park provides suitable habitat variety wildlife including least 215 bird species. Light Detection Ranging (LiDAR) active remote sensing technology. performed using laser scanners emit pulses light determine position target 3D objects measuring amount time pulses emitted received. revolutionary technology helps acquisition extremely accurate digital elevation data wide spatial temporal scales. info examples LiDAR data resources specific province, see LiDAR Data Resources end Chapter.

title: Chapter 4 - Elevation Data
text: read National Park polygons R, navigate Places administered Parks Canada, click “Go Resource” download. haven’t already, return Chapter 2 Learning Objectives view (getwd()) set (setwd()) working directory create folder within directory called data. store data used tutorial series. Create subdirectory called nationalparks neatly store parks spatial data. Move files Downloads nationalparks subdirectory applying st_read() function. Filter national_parks dataset La Mauricie National Park. OPTIONAL: save boundary shapefile working directory, use st_write() function. boundary files used subsequent chapters. uploaded Google Drive data folder convenience. Create subdirectory called boundary neatly store boundary files. execute code chunk, remove # assess species distribution within National Park, download data Quebec Breeding Bird Atlas (2010 - 2014) 5 year census collects data distribution abundance species breeding province. Don’t forget replace testuser NatureCounts username. prompted password. Download NatureCounts data: Read list species names NatureCounts can linked species id: create date doy columns ensure ObservationCount column correct numeric format can apply format_dates() mutate() functions. also filter dataset exclude rows missing coordinates. convert NatureCounts data spatial object transform coordinate reference system (CRS) match National Park boundary can use st_as_sf() st_transform() functions, respectively. Clip NatureCounts point data National Park boundary using st_intersection(). Append species names clipped NatureCounts dataset based species_id code. Tidyverse functions can help us summarize data variety ways. example, can determine annual total count birds year across sites. use group_by() function group observations year, summarise() calculate create annual_count column. wanted summarize total count species Atlas Block adjust pipe using pivot_wider(). Drop geometry column convert filtered NatureCounts data back regular dataframe. Select key attributes reduce dataframe. OPTIONAL: save NatureCounts data .csv disk, use write.csv() function, specify name .csv file, use row.names = FALSE argument exclude row numbers output. filtered NatureCounts dataset used subsequent chapters. uploaded file Google Drive data folder convenience. execute code chunk, remove #
code: dir.create("data/nationalparks", recursive = TRUE) # specify the path to your shapefile national_parks <- st_read("path/to/your/shapefile.shp") View(national_parks) # to find the correct object ID  mauricie_boundary <- national_parks %>%   filter(OBJECTID == "21")  # Drop the Z-dimension (3D component) to make it 2D mauricie_boundary <- st_zm(mauricie_boundary, drop = TRUE, what = "ZM") dir.create("data/boundary", recursive = TRUE) # st_write(mauricie_boundary, "data/boundary/mauricie_boundary.shp")   # st_write(mauricie_boundary, "data/boundary/mauricie_boundary.kml", driver="KML") quebec_atlas <- nc_data_dl(   collections = "QCATLAS2PC",     username = "testuser", info = "spatial_data_tutorial", timeout = 1000) species_names <- search_species() quebec_atlas <- quebec_atlas %>%   format_dates() %>%  # create the date and doy columns    mutate(ObservationCount = as.numeric(ObservationCount)) %>%  # convert to numeric format   filter(!is.na(longitude) & !is.na(latitude))  # remove rows with missing coordinates quebec_atlas_sf <- sf::st_as_sf(quebec_atlas,                         coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) # converts the quebec_atlas data to an sf object, crs = 4326 is WGS84 which corresponds to the NatureCounts data  mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(quebec_atlas_sf)) # match the CRS between the polygon and point data mauricie_birds_sf <- sf::st_intersection(quebec_atlas_sf, mauricie_boundary) mauricie_birds_sf <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   left_join(species_names, by = "species_id") mauricie_birds_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   group_by(survey_year) %>%   summarise(annual_count = sum(ObservationCount, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% # calculates the annual_count   filter(!is.na(survey_year))  # remove rows with missing year  mauricie_birds_summary #> Simple feature collection with 4 features and 2 fields #> Geometry type: MULTIPOINT #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -73.12685 ymin: 46.65015 xmax: -72.77968 ymax: 46.82687 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   survey_year annual_count                                                                                  geometry #> *       <int>        <dbl>                                                                          <MULTIPOINT [°]> #> 1        2011          909 ((-72.83548 46.76367), (-72.83824 46.76044), (-72.84852 46.75341), (-72.85742 46.74331... #> 2        2012          578 ((-72.77968 46.74193), (-72.80576 46.75797), (-72.80941 46.75672), (-72.83613 46.77124... #> 3        2013          517 ((-72.80942 46.75671), (-72.83614 46.77124), (-72.84853 46.75341), (-72.82786 46.74054... #> 4        2014         1396 ((-72.77968 46.74193), (-72.80576 46.75797), (-72.80941 46.75672), (-72.83613 46.77124... mauricie_species_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%  # drop the geometry column   group_by(english_name, Locality) %>%   summarise(total_count = sum(ObservationCount, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% # calculates the total_count column   pivot_wider(names_from = english_name, # populates the column names with each species common name               values_from = total_count, # populates each cell with total_count               values_fill = list(total_count = 0)) # missing values are zero-filled #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'english_name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.   View(mauricie_species_summary) mauricie_birds_df <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%  # Drops the geometry column   bind_cols(     st_coordinates(mauricie_birds_sf) %>%  # Extract coordinates       as.data.frame()  # Convert the coordinates to a data.frame   ) %>%   rename(longitude = X, latitude = Y)  mauricie_birds_df <- mauricie_birds_df %>% dplyr::select(record_id, species_id, english_name, SiteCode, survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, ObservationCount, longitude, latitude) # reduce the dataframe to the columns needed for your analysis # write.csv(mauricie_birds_df, "data/mauricie_birds_df.csv", row.names = FALSE)

title: Chapter 4 - Elevation Data
text: Digital elevation datasets store topographic information like elevation slope often used landscape ecology. datasets, .e., Digital Elevation Models (DEMs), Digital Surface Models (DSMs), Digital Terrain Models (DTMs) derived variety remote sensing spatial interpolation techniques help describe land features. Digital Elevation Model - represents bare-Earth surface excludes terrain vector features (.e., streams, breaklines, ridges), ground objects (power lines, buildings, trees, vegetation). Digital Surface Model - represents heights Earth’s surface includes natural artificial features ground objects. Digital Terrain Model - represents bare-Earth surface topography includes terrain vector features. include natural artificial ground objects. words, DEM augmented presence streams, breaklines, ridges. quick-access elevation data, download .tif files URL using hyperlinks . wish gain experience -access LiDAR data , follow steps end Chapter. Click following hyperlinks download LiDAR-derived elevation data tiles 31I14NE, 31I15NO, 31I14SE, 31I15SO, 31I11NE, 31I10NO, respectively move folder named dtm stored data subdirectory. Create subdirectory called dtm neatly store downloaded TIF files. Move Downloads dtm folder. Set path TIF file subdirectory. Create mosaic adjacent DTM rasters. Reminder: store DTM’s folder download. code produce error .tif files subdirectory (like ones downloaded Chapter 3). use stars package allows us create ‘proxy’ objects, meaning files aren’t loaded memory absolutely must . allows us work much quickly files, especially plotting. Let’s check DTM National Park boundary crs using st_crs() function equality operator (==) generate either TRUE FALSE. reproject spatial data CRS, can use st_transform() function.
code: dir.create("data/dtm", recursive = TRUE) # list all the TIFF files in your directory dtm_files <- list.files(output_dir, pattern = "\\.tif$", full.names = TRUE)   # Combine into a single stars object (use proxy to only load what we need) dtm_mosaic <- st_mosaic(dtm_files) dtm_mosaic <- read_stars(dtm_mosaic, proxy = TRUE) st_crs(dtm_mosaic) == st_crs(mauricie_boundary) #> [1] FALSE mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(dtm_mosaic))

Chapter 5, explore extract unique pixel values landcover data link NatureCounts data. additional resources may find useful understanding LiDAR data.
code: # Plot dtm_mosaic plot(dtm_mosaic, main = "regional DTM",       col = viridisLite::viridis(n = 100), reset = FALSE) # reset = FALSE allows us to stack plots #> downsample set to 37  # Overlay the National Park boundary on the first plot plot(st_as_sfc(mauricie_boundary), add = TRUE, border = "red", lwd = 2) # Plot dtm_mask plot(dtm_crop, main = "masked DTM",       col = viridisLite::viridis(n = 100), reset = FALSE) #> downsample set to 28 # Overlay the National Park boundary on the second plot #plot(st_as_sfc(mauricie_boundary), add = TRUE, border = "red", lwd = 2, col = NA, reset = FALSE) # Group by SiteCode and summarize mean annual count across all species mauricie_site_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%    summarise(n_species = n_distinct(english_name)) # count the number of unique species #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'SiteCode'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. # Match the CRS mauricie_site_summary <- st_transform(mauricie_site_summary, crs = st_crs(dtm_crop))  # Plot the dtm_mask raster plot(dtm_crop,       main = "Elevation with Species Diversity Summary Points across La Mauricie",      col = viridisLite::viridis(n = 100), reset = FALSE) #> downsample set to 28  # Overlay the National Park boundary in red plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary),       col = NA, border = "red", lwd = 2,       reset = FALSE, add = TRUE)  #scale the n_species column to range from 0-5 for plotting mauricie_site_summary$n_species_scale <- scales::rescale(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, to = c(0, 2))  # Overlay mauricie_site_summary points plot(st_geometry(mauricie_site_summary),       pch = 19,        # Solid circle      col = "black",   # Point color      cex = mauricie_site_summary$n_species_scale, # Point size based on total      reset = FALSE, add = TRUE)        # Define legend values for the point size scale legend_values <- c(min(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE),                     median(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE),                     max(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE)) legend_sizes <- scales::rescale(legend_values, to = c(0.5, 2))  # Add legend for the point size scale beside elevation scale legend("topright",                     # Position        inset = c(-0.10, 0),            # Moves the legend outside the map extent        legend = legend_values,         pch = 19, col = "black",         pt.cex = legend_sizes,         title = "Species Richness",        title.cex = 0.7,                # Adjust legend title size        bty = "y",                      # Place box around legend        xpd = TRUE)                     # Allows placing legend outside the plot names(dtm_crop) <- "elevation" # Match the CRS mauricie_birds_sf <- st_transform(mauricie_birds_sf, crs = st_crs(dtm_crop))  # Extract the elevation values for each site elevation_values_sf <- stars::st_extract(dtm_crop, mauricie_birds_sf) elevation_values_sf <- bind_cols(elevation_values_sf,                                   st_drop_geometry(mauricie_birds_sf)) %>%   dplyr::select(SiteCode, elevation) elevation_values_df <- elevation_values_sf %>%    group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%   mutate(point_id = cur_group_id()) %>%    select(point_id, elevation) %>%    distinct() %>%   ungroup() %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%  # drop the geometry column   as.data.frame()  # convert to a regular dataframe   # Note that usually the SiteCode is the unique identifier for each observation site. However, this was not the case for the Quebec Breeding Bird Atlas data. We therefore use the geometry to create a unique identifier for each point. dir.create("data/env_covariates", recursive = TRUE) # write.csv(elevation_values_df, "data/env_covariates/elevation_values_df.csv", row.names = FALSE) mauricie_site_summary <- st_transform(mauricie_site_summary, crs = st_crs(dtm_crop))  # Extract the elevation values for each site elevation_sitesum_sf <- stars::st_extract(dtm_crop, mauricie_site_summary) %>%   bind_cols(st_drop_geometry(mauricie_site_summary))  # Plot the relationship between elevation and species diversity  plot(elevation_sitesum_sf$elevation, elevation_sitesum_sf$n_species,       xlab = "Elevation (m)", ylab = "Number of Species",       main = "Species Diversity vs. Elevation")

code: mauricie_boundary <- st_read("path/to/your/mauricie_boundary.shp") # set the path to your landcover data landcover <- rast("path/to/your/landcover-2015-classification.tif") print(landcover) #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 160001, 190001, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 30, 30  (x, y) #> extent      : -2600010, 3100020, -885090, 3914940  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : NAD83(CSRS) / Canada Atlas Lambert (EPSG:3979)  #> source      : landcover-2015-classification.tif  #> color table : 1  #> name        : Canada2015 mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(landcover))

title: Chapter 5 - Land Cover Data
text: Cropping reduces extent raster extent another raster vector. crop raster can apply crop() function terra package uses SpatVector format. , crop extent land cover raster extent National Park. need convert National Park Boundary SpatVector using vect(). Masking assigns NA values cells raster covered vector. mask landcover raster National Parks vector extent can apply mask() function terra package also uses SpatVector format. apply NA values cells outside extent National Park. Visualize cropped masked land cover rasters two-panel plot.  OPTIONAL: write masked raster disk, can use writeRaster() function terra. raster used Chapter 7: Summary Tools. uploaded file Google Drive data folder convenience subfolder labeled mauricie. execute code chunk, remove # make sure specify file format (.tif) output path Note: Make sure include ‘.tif’ argument specifying output_dir name masked raster file. specifies file type using writeRaster() , otherwise, produce error.
code: landcover_crop <- crop(landcover, vect(mauricie_boundary)) print(landcover_crop) #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 967, 1027, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 30, 30  (x, y) #> extent      : 1650060, 1680870, 28020, 57030  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : NAD83(CSRS) / Canada Atlas Lambert (EPSG:3979)  #> source(s)   : memory #> color table : 1  #> varname     : landcover-2015-classification  #> name        : Canada2015  #> min value   :          1  #> max value   :         18 landcover_mask <- mask(landcover_crop, vect(mauricie_boundary)) print(landcover_mask) #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 967, 1027, 1  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 30, 30  (x, y) #> extent      : 1650060, 1680870, 28020, 57030  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : NAD83(CSRS) / Canada Atlas Lambert (EPSG:3979)  #> source(s)   : memory #> color table : 1  #> varname     : landcover-2015-classification  #> name        : Canada2015  #> min value   :          1  #> max value   :         18 # Set up the plot area for 1 row and 2 columns par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Plot the cropped land cover raster plot(landcover_crop, main = "crop")  # Add National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="purple", lwd = 2, add = TRUE)  # Plot the masked land cover raster  plot(landcover_mask, main = "mask")  # Add National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="purple", lwd = 2, add = TRUE) # Reset plotting layout to default par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) # output_dir <- "path/to/your/subdirectory/data/landcover_mask.tif" # include the masked raster name and '.tif' argument   # writeRaster(landcover_mask, output_dir, overwrite = TRUE)

title: Chapter 5 - Land Cover Data
text: assign appropriate labels land cover class, refer [Class Index](https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/ee1580ab-a23d-4f86-a09b-79763677eb47/resource/b8411562-49b7-4cf6-ac61-dbb893b182cc)) use case_when() function. Now can plot cropped land cover raster meaningful names using ggplot().
code: landcover_mask_df <- as.data.frame(landcover_mask, xy = TRUE, cells = TRUE)  list(unique(landcover_mask_df$Canada2015)) # determine unique land cover class values in the cropped dataset #> [[1]] #> [1]  5  8  6  1 18 17 10 14 16  land_cover_data <- landcover_mask_df %>%   arrange(Canada2015) %>%  # Sort by land_cover_value   mutate(landcover_name = case_when(     Canada2015 == 1 ~ "needleleaf",     Canada2015 == 5 ~ "broadleaf",     Canada2015 == 6 ~ "mixed forest",     Canada2015 == 8 ~ "shrubland",     Canada2015 == 10 ~ "grassland",     Canada2015 == 14 ~ "wetland",     Canada2015 == 16 ~ "barren",     Canada2015 == 17 ~ "urban",     Canada2015 == 18 ~ "water",     TRUE ~ NA_character_  # Handle any unexpected values   )) ggplot() +   geom_raster(data = land_cover_data, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = landcover_name)) +   labs(     title = "La Mauricie National Park - Landcover 2015",     x = "Longitude",     y = "Latitude"   ) +   theme_bw() +   coord_fixed() +   geom_sf(data = mauricie_boundary, fill = NA, color = "purple", size = 1.5) #> Coordinate system already present. Adding new coordinate system, which will replace the existing one.

title: Chapter 5 - Land Cover Data
text: Buffers allow us generate polygons specified distance around points, lines polygons. birds use habitat landscape-level single observation point, buffers allow us summarize land cover habitat information within local neighborhood. Read NatureCounts data saved Chapter 4: Elevation Data downloaded Google Drive data folder. Note: land cover data (2015) represents static environmental variable scenario. , assume land cover within National Park change drastically across survey years (2011 - 2014). Create sf object NatureCounts data represents unique point count locations. Assign point id identifier location based unique geometry. Use st_buffer function generate 3 km diameter circular neighborhoods (1.5 km radius) centered observation location.
code: mauricie_birds_df <- read.csv("path/to/your/mauricie_birds_df.csv") mauricie_birds_local <- mauricie_birds_df %>%    st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) mauricie_birds_local <- mauricie_birds_local %>%    group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%   mutate(point_id = cur_group_id()) %>%    dplyr::select(geometry, point_id) %>%    distinct() %>% ungroup()  #Note that usually the SiteCode is the unique identifier for each observation site. However, this was not the case for the Quebec Breeding Bird Atlas data. We therefore use the geometry to create a unique identifier for each point. mauricie_birds_buffer <- mauricie_birds_local %>%   st_buffer(dist = set_units(1.5, "km"))

title: Chapter 5 - Land Cover Data
text: landscape ecology, composition configuration land types tells us habitat available distributed spatially. Landscape metrics help us characterize spatial patterns across landscapes within specific areas like point buffers. landscapemetrics package can used calculate common metrics quantify habitat composition configuration: Percent landcover (PLAND) - percent landscape given class Edge density (ED) - total boundary length patches given class per unit area Number patches (NP) - number unique contiguous units Largest patch index (LPI) - percent landscape comprised single largest patch Mean core area index (CAI_MN) - percent patch comprised core area compound measure shape, area, edge depth. Patch cohesion index (COHESION) - area-weighted mean perimeter-area ratio helps assess connectivity “patch” intuitive concept describes contiguous group cells land cover category. Patches can defined using 4-neighbour 8-neighbour rules. point buffer, crop mask land cover data calculate class-level PLAND ED. using loop store result dataframe. Add land cover class labels dataframe containing calculated landscape metrics. Ensure columns data type (factor). Create PLAND column land cover type, associated point_id. Note: every land cover type represented within point buffer, hence rows might populated NA values. Calculate mean class-level PLAND ED across point buffers. Compare mean class-level PLAND ED values.  appears like ‘mixed forest’ dominant land cover type across point buffers. class also highest edge density. Calculate landscape-level ED NP point buffer. Store result dataframe. Note: Landscape pattern analysis requires careful consideration classification scheme, spatial extent, choice landscape metric - depend objectives study. group values also matters influence interpret results.
code: lsm <- list()  for (i in seq_len(nrow(mauricie_birds_buffer))) {   buffer_i <- st_transform(mauricie_birds_buffer[i, ], crs = crs(landcover))  # Match the CRS between the buffer zones and land cover      # Crop and mask the landcover data with the buffer areas   lsm[[i]] <- crop(landcover, buffer_i) %>%      mask(buffer_i) %>%       # Calculate landscape metrics     calculate_lsm(level = "class", metric = c("pland", "ed")) %>%      # Add identifying variables     mutate(point_id= buffer_i$point_id) %>%       dplyr::select(point_id, level, class, metric, value) }  # Combine results into a single dataframe lsm <- bind_rows(lsm) # Define the land cover class labels  lc_classes <- land_cover_data %>% dplyr::select(Canada2015, landcover_name) %>% distinct()  lc_classes <-lc_classes %>% mutate(class = as.factor(Canada2015)) lsm<-lsm %>% mutate(class = as.factor(class))  lsm <- inner_join(lc_classes, lsm, by = "class") pland_values <- lsm %>%   filter(metric == "pland") %>%                      # Filter for 'pland' metric   dplyr::select(point_id, landcover_name, value) %>%        # Keep relevant columns   pivot_wider(     names_from = landcover_name,                     # Create columns for each landcover class     values_from = value,                             # Fill columns with 'pland' values     names_prefix = "pland_"                          # Prefix column names with "pland_"   ) lsm_mean <- lsm %>%   group_by(landcover_name, metric) %>%    summarise(mean_value = mean(value, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")   # View the resulting dataframe print(lsm_mean) #> # A tibble: 18 × 3 #>    landcover_name metric mean_value #>    <chr>          <chr>       <dbl> #>  1 barren         ed         0.167  #>  2 barren         pland      0.0130 #>  3 broadleaf      ed        39.8    #>  4 broadleaf      pland     12.2    #>  5 grassland      ed         2.16   #>  6 grassland      pland      0.248  #>  7 mixed forest   ed       115.     #>  8 mixed forest   pland     54.8    #>  9 needleleaf     ed        79.2    #> 10 needleleaf     pland     20.4    #> 11 shrubland      ed        12.5    #> 12 shrubland      pland      1.32   #> 13 urban          ed         5.24   #> 14 urban          pland      0.561  #> 15 water          ed        15.5    #> 16 water          pland     10.5    #> 17 wetland        ed         0.400  #> 18 wetland        pland      0.0362 # Plot mean PLAND and ED for each landcover class ggplot(lsm_mean, aes(x = landcover_name, y = mean_value, color = metric)) +   geom_point(size = 4, alpha = 0.8, position = position_dodge(width = 0.4)) +   labs(title = "Mean PLAND and ED for Each Landcover Class",        x = "Landcover Class",        y = "Mean Value",        color = "Metric") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("ed" = "red", "pland" = "darkgreen")) lsm_landscape <- list()  for (i in seq_len(nrow(mauricie_birds_buffer))) {   buffer_i <- st_transform(mauricie_birds_buffer[i, ], crs = crs(landcover))  # Match the CRS between the buffer zones and land cover      # Crop and mask the landcover data with the buffer areas   lsm_landscape[[i]] <- crop(landcover, buffer_i) %>%      mask(buffer_i) %>%       # Calculate landscape metrics     calculate_lsm(level = "landscape", metric = c("np", "ed")) %>%      # Add identifying variables     mutate(point_id= buffer_i$point_id,             survey_year = buffer_i$survey_year) %>%       dplyr::select(point_id, level, metric, value) }  # Combine results into a single dataframe and convert to wide format lsm_landscape <- lsm_landscape %>%   bind_rows() %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = "metric",               values_from = "value")

code: mauricie_birds_sf <- sf::st_as_sf(mauricie_birds_df,                          coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326)    # convert to sf object  mauricie_birds_sf <- st_join(mauricie_birds_sf, mauricie_birds_local, join = st_intersects) mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(mauricie_birds_sf)) # match the CRS # Group by point_id and summarize total_count mauricie_site_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   group_by(point_id) %>% filter(!is.na(point_id)) %>% # Filter out NA values   summarise(n_species = n_distinct(english_name)) # Match the CRS mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(landcover))   # Plot ggplot() +   # Add the raster layer   geom_raster(data = land_cover_data, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = landcover_name)) +      # Add the National Park boundary in red   geom_sf(data = mauricie_boundary, fill = NA, color = "purple", size = 0.9) +      # Add the multipoints from the site summary, sized by total_count   geom_sf(data = mauricie_site_summary, aes(size = n_species), color = "black", shape = 21) +      # Adjust the size scale for points   scale_size_continuous(name = "Species Diversity", range = c(1, 6)) +  # Adjust the range for better visibility      # Add labels and theme   labs(     title = "La Mauricie National Park - Landcover 2015",     x = "Longitude",     y = "Latitude"   ) +   theme_bw() +      # Use coord_sf for compatibility with sf layers   coord_sf() landscape_metrics_df <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%   distinct(point_id, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%  # Ensure no duplicates based on point_id, but keep all columns   left_join(lsm_landscape, by = "point_id") %>%   dplyr::select(point_id, ed, np)  # Keep point_id, ed, and np columns landscape_metrics_df <- landscape_metrics_df %>%   left_join(pland_values, by = "point_id") # write.csv(landscape_metrics_df , "data/env_covariates/landscape_metrics_df.csv", row.names = FALSE) # Join the landscape metrics with the NatureCounts summary data lsm_sitesum_df <- left_join(mauricie_site_summary, landscape_metrics_df, by = "point_id")  # Plot the relationship between species diversity and edge density and the number of patches, respectively  # n_species vs. edge density (ED) ggplot(lsm_sitesum_df, aes(x = ed, y = n_species)) +   geom_point(color = "blue", alpha = 0.6) +   labs(title = "Species Diversity vs. Edge Density",        x = "Edge Density (ED)",        y = "Number of Species") +   theme_minimal() # n_species vs. number of patches (NP) ggplot(lsm_sitesum_df, aes(x = np, y = n_species)) +   geom_point(color = "green", alpha = 0.6) +   labs(title = "Species Diversity vs. Number of Patches",        x = "Number of Patches (NP)",        y = "Number of Species") +   theme_minimal()

title: Chapter 6 - Satellite Imagery
text: Multispectral sensors measure amount light energy reflected surface features. reflection occurs depends factors like surface roughness object (relative wavelength energy) incidence angle energy strikes. Every surface material distinct spectral signature describes percentage radiation reflected object different wavelengths. vegetation, spectral reflectance also depends structural components leaves: pigments like chrolophyll & b, beta-carotene palisade mesophyll (outer leaf), near-infrared (NIR) scattering spongy mesophyll (inner leaf), water content. Healthy vegetation (chlorophyll, high water content) absorbs visible light, reflects NIR, absorbs middle-infrared (MIR). type interactions basis calculating spectral indices, explored next section. interactions also mean can represent multispectral imagery color composites strategically emphasize surface properties using combinations different bands (range wavelengths): Natural (True) Color Composites - use visible red, green, blue (RGB) bands respective color channels depict human eye naturally see. False Color Composites - use non-visible band like NIR, MIR, SWIR RGB color channels depict wavelengths invisible naked eye. Different band combinations help highlight surface features. Specify path folder containing satellite images code chunk . image represents distinct band. downloaded data following Section 6.3, look folder labeled S2A_MSIL2A. Copy file path S2A_MSIL2A… > GRANULE > L2A… > IMG_DATA > R10m contains satellite images use . Read National Park boundary saved downloaded Chapter 4: Elevation Data. Transform coordinate reference system (CRS) National Park boundary match sentinel_imagery SpatRaster. Crop sentinel_imagery extent mauricie_boundary plot cropped image true color.  Now plot cropped image false color. , ’ll use standard false color composite red, green, blue channels used visualize NIR, red, green respectively.
code: bands <- list.files(path = here::here("misc/data/R10m"), # drop `here::here()` and specify the path to your folder                     pattern = "\\.jp2$", full.names = TRUE)  # Read all the bands into a raster stack  sentinel_imagery <- rast(bands)  # Assign meaningful names to the bands names(sentinel_imagery) <- c("AOT", "blue", "green", "red", "nir", "TCI_r", "TCI_g", "TCI_b", "WVP")  # Check the assigned names print(names(sentinel_imagery)) #> [1] "AOT"   "blue"  "green" "red"   "nir"   "TCI_r" "TCI_g" "TCI_b" "WVP"  # Check resolution, number of layers, and extent res(sentinel_imagery) #> [1] 10 10 nlyr(sentinel_imagery) #> [1] 9 ext(sentinel_imagery) #> SpatExtent : 6e+05, 709800, 5090220, 5200020 (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) mauricie_boundary <- st_read("path/to/your/mauricie_boundary.shp") mauricie_boundary <- mauricie_boundary %>%   sf::st_make_valid() %>% # fix performance issues with layer + faster computation   st_transform(crs = st_crs(sentinel_imagery)) mauricie_sl <- crop(sentinel_imagery, vect(mauricie_boundary))  # Plot the RGB composite terra::plotRGB(mauricie_sl, r = 4, g = 3, b = 2, stretch = "lin", lwd = 2, axes = FALSE)  # Add the boundary shapefile to the plot plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="red", add = TRUE) # Plot the false color composite terra::plotRGB(mauricie_sl, r = 5, g = 4, b = 3, stretch = "lin", lwd = 2, axes = FALSE)  # Add the boundary shapefile to the plot plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="green", add = TRUE)

title: Chapter 6 - Satellite Imagery
text: Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI; Huang et al., 2021) common proxy primary productivity collected using remote sensing. measure vegetation health describes greenness density vegetation captured satellite image. Healthy vegetation absorb visible light reflect near-infrared light, depending structural integrity amount chlorophyll found biomass. Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI; McFeeters, 1996) spectral index can used detect water bodies multispectral imagery. NDWI can used create water mask help minimize effect water avoid skewed vegetation index values removing water values image. words, help make calculation NDVI accurate. Applying mode filter water mask creates uniformity across water eliminating areas might confused land cover types. Annual cumulative NDVI strong positive relationship species richness bird diversity time, making useful covariate describe trends NatureCounts data. section, calculate two spectral indices: 1) NDWI create water mask 2) NDVI measure vegetation health. Create water mask using following function: NDWI=GREEN−NIRGREEN+NIRNDWI = \frac{GREEN - NIR}{GREEN + NIR} Plot NDWI water mask.  Use function focal() apply convolution filter returning mode pixel water_mask 3 x 3 windows equal weights (argument w = 3). Name output raster water_mask_mode. mode vector x value appears often x. Calculate water_mask_mode. Combine water_mask water_mask_mode. Assign meaningful names raster mask plot .  Look closely side--side depictions water mask water mask mode . Notice tiny yellow areas previously identified water water mask extent now absent water mask mode extent? Apply water_mask_mode mauricie_sl. Apply another mask assign NA values pixels outside National Park boundary. Plot true color composite mauricie_sl_mask National Park boundary.  calculate NDVI, create apply following function masked satellite image: NDVI=NIR−REDNIR+REDNDVI = \frac{NIR - RED}{NIR + RED}
code: calc_ndwi <- function(green, nir) {   ndwi <- c((green - nir)/(green + nir))   return(ndwi) }  # Calculate NDWI mauricie_sl_ndwi <- calc_ndwi(mauricie_sl$green, mauricie_sl$nir)  # Create water mask water_mask <- mauricie_sl_ndwi >= 0 # Set up the plot area for 1 row and 2 columns par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Plot NDWI plot(mauricie_sl_ndwi, main = "NDWI")  # Add National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="red", add = TRUE)  # Plot water mask  plot(water_mask, main = "Water mask")  # Add National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="red", add = TRUE) # Reset plotting layout to default par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) get_mode <- function(x, na.rm = TRUE) {      if (na.rm) {     x <- x[!is.na(x)]   }      ux <- unique(x)      ux[which.max(tabulate(match(x, ux)))]    } water_mask_mode <- focal(water_mask, w = 3, fun = get_mode) water_mask_combined <- c(water_mask, water_mask_mode) names(water_mask_combined) <- c("water mask", "water mask mode")  plot(water_mask_combined) mauricie_sl_water_mask <- mask(mauricie_sl, water_mask_mode, maskvalues = 1) mauricie_sl_mask <- mask(mauricie_sl_water_mask, vect(mauricie_boundary)) # Plot RGB with both water and boundary masks applied terra::plotRGB(mauricie_sl_mask, r = 4, g = 3, b = 2, stretch = "lin", axes = FALSE)  # Add the National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="red", add = TRUE) calc_ndvi <- function(nir, red) {   ndvi <- c((nir - red)/(nir  + red))   return(ndvi) }  # Calculate NDVI  mauricie_sl_ndvi <- calc_ndvi(mauricie_sl_mask$nir, mauricie_sl_mask$red)

code: # Plot NDVI plot(mauricie_sl_ndvi, main = "NDVI values across La Mauricie National Park")  # Add the National Park boundary plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border ="red", add = TRUE) names(mauricie_sl_ndvi) <- "ndvi" mauricie_birds_df <- read_csv("path/to/your/mauricie_birds_df.csv") mauricie_birds_sf <- sf::st_as_sf(mauricie_birds_df,                          coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326)              # convert to sf object  mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(mauricie_birds_sf)) # match the CRS mauricie_boundary <- st_transform(mauricie_boundary, crs = st_crs(mauricie_birds_sf)) # match the CRS # Group by SiteCode and summarize mean annual count across all species mauricie_site_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%    summarise(n_species = n_distinct(english_name)) # count the number of unique species #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'SiteCode'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. # Match the CRS mauricie_site_summary <- st_transform(mauricie_site_summary, crs = st_crs(mauricie_sl_ndvi))  # Plot the dtm_mask raster plot(mauricie_sl_ndvi, main = "NDVI with Species Diversity Summary Points across La Mauricie")  # Overlay the National Park boundary in red plot(st_geometry(mauricie_boundary), col = NA, border = "red", add = TRUE, lwd = 2)  #scale the n_species column to range from 0-5 for plotting mauricie_site_summary$n_species_scale <- scales::rescale(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, to = c(0, 2))  # Overlay mauricie_site_summary points plot(st_geometry(mauricie_site_summary),       add = TRUE,       pch = 19,       # Solid circle      col = "black",   # Point color      cex = mauricie_site_summary$n_species_scale)      # Point size based on total  # Define legend values for the point size scale legend_values <- c(min(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE),                     median(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE),                     max(mauricie_site_summary$n_species, na.rm = TRUE)) legend_sizes <- scales::rescale(legend_values, to = c(0.5, 2))  # Add legend for the point size scale beside NDVI scale legend("topright",                     # Position        inset = c(-0.12, 0),            # Moves the legend outside the map extent        legend = legend_values,         pch = 19, col = "black",         pt.cex = legend_sizes,         title = "Species Richness",        title.cex = 0.6,                # Adjust legend title size        bty = "y",                      # Place box around legend        xpd = TRUE)                     # Allows placing legend outside the plot mauricie_birds_sf <- st_transform(mauricie_birds_sf, crs = st_crs(mauricie_sl_ndvi)) # Match the CRS  ndvi_values_sv <- terra::extract(mauricie_sl_ndvi, vect(mauricie_birds_sf), bind = TRUE) # Extracts the NDVI values for each point ndvi_values_sf <- ndvi_values_sv %>%   st_as_sf() %>% # converts to sf object   dplyr::select(SiteCode, ndvi, geometry) # select relevant columns ndvi_values_df <- ndvi_values_sf %>%    group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%   mutate(point_id = cur_group_id()) %>%    dplyr::select(point_id, ndvi) %>%    distinct() %>%   ungroup() %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%  # drop the geometry column   as.data.frame()  # convert to a regular dataframe   # Note that usually the SiteCode is the unique identifier for each observation site. However, this was not the case for the Quebec Breeding Bird Atlas data. We therefore use the geometry to create a unique identifier for each point. # write.csv(ndvi_values_df, "data/env_covariates/ndvi_values_df.csv", row.names = FALSE) mauricie_site_summary <- st_transform(mauricie_site_summary, crs = st_crs(mauricie_sl_ndvi))  # Extract the elevation values for each site ndvi_sitesum_sf <- terra::extract(mauricie_sl_ndvi, vect(mauricie_site_summary), bind = TRUE)  # Plot the relationship between ndvi and species diversity  plot(ndvi_sitesum_sf$ndvi, ndvi_sitesum_sf$n_species,       xlab = "NDVI", ylab = "Number of Species",       main = "Species Diversity vs. NDVI")
