code: if (!dir.exists("data/env_covariates")) { # checks if "env_covariates" subdirectory exists   print("Subdirectory does not exist. Creating now...")   dir.create("data/env_covariates", recursive = TRUE) # if not, creates subdirectory } else {   print("Subdirectory already exists.") } #> [1] "Subdirectory already exists." # List the dataframes env_covariates <- list.files(path = here::here("misc/data/env_covariates"), # drop `here::here()` and paste appropriate path to your data                              pattern = "\\.csv$",                               full.names = TRUE)  # Read each CSV into a list of dataframes env_covariates_list <- lapply(env_covariates, read_csv)  # Combine NatureCounts and environmental covariates  env_covariates_df <- Reduce(function(x, y) left_join(x, y, by = "point_id"), env_covariates_list) mauricie_birds_df <- read_csv(path/to/your/mauricie_birds_df.csv")) mauricie_birds_sf <- mauricie_birds_df %>%    st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) mauricie_birds_sf <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%    dplyr::select(SiteCode, survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, english_name, ObservationCount, geometry) mauricie_birds_summary <- mauricie_birds_sf %>%   group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%   mutate(point_id = cur_group_id()) %>%   ungroup() %>%   distinct() %>%   st_drop_geometry(mauricie_birds_summary) # drops geometry and converts to regular dataframe biodiversity_count <- mauricie_birds_summary  %>%   group_by(point_id) %>%   summarise(n_species = n_distinct(english_name),             n_individuals = sum(ObservationCount, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") # Count unique species enviro_data_df <- env_covariates_df %>%   left_join(biodiversity_count, by = "point_id") %>%   rename(pland_mixed_forest = `pland_mixed forest`) %>%  # Rename column   mutate(across(-point_id, as.numeric))  # Ensure all other columns are numeric

title: Chapter 7 - Spatial Summary Tools
text: Species rank plots show relative abundance (number individuals) species community. number individuals species sorted ascending descending order. Group NatureCounts data species rank order abundance. Plot abundance species rank across entire park.
code: species_rank <- mauricie_birds_summary %>%   filter(!is.na(english_name)) %>%  # Remove rows with NA in english_name   group_by(english_name) %>%  # Group by species only   summarize(total_abundance = sum(ObservationCount, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") %>%   arrange(desc(total_abundance)) %>%  # Sort in descending order of abundance   slice_max(total_abundance, n = 40) %>%  # Keep only the top 40 species   mutate(rank = row_number())  # Assign rank to each species ggplot(species_rank, aes(x = reorder(english_name, rank), y = total_abundance)) +   geom_line(group = 1, size = 1, color = "black") +   geom_point(size = 2, color = "darkgreen") +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Abundance of High Rank Species across La Mauricie Park",     x = "Species",     y = "Total Abundance"   ) +   theme(     axis.text.x = element_text(size = 8, angle = 60, hjust = 1)   )

code: # Elevation vs. n_species ggplot(enviro_data_df, aes(x = elevation, y = n_species)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", col = "blue") +   labs(title = "Relationship between Elevation and Species Richness") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' # PLAND vs. n_species ggplot(enviro_data_df, aes(x = pland_mixed_forest, y = n_species)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", col = "blue") +   labs(title = "Relationship between PLAND and Species Richness") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' # Edge Density vs. n_species ggplot(enviro_data_df, aes(x = ed, y = n_species)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", col = "blue") +   labs(title = "Relationship between Edge Density and Species Richness") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' # NDVI vs. n_species ggplot(enviro_data_df, aes(x = ndvi, y = n_species)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", col = "blue") +   labs(title = "Relationship between NDVI and Species Richness") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Chapter 7 - Spatial Summary Tools
text: Create events matrix containing geometry unique survey event location. Recall NatureCounts datasets unique SiteCode survey point. However, case Quebec Breeding Bird Atlas, step required Assign point id identifier location based unique geometry return result dataframe. Restore longitude latitude columns, drop geometry, convert dataframe, keep relevant columns. Join environmental variables events matrix based point_id. Filter NatureCounts data species interest merge events matrix species-specific data. result NA values events species observed. Zero-fill specific species. , replace NA values ObservationColumn 0 select column interest inspect data. Create Presence/Absence column based ObservationCount. Create bar plot summarize Presence/Absence data, grouped survey_year.  Now can explore Golden-crowned Kinglet presence/absence related environmental covariates. First create box plot single covariate.  can create boxplot multiple covariates using pivot_longer function.  Users may wish explore data using simple statistics, like logistic regression, create response curves showing relationship covariates probability species present. edge density increase, probability Golden Crown Kinglet increase slightly. Users can explore relationships environmental covariates. ________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ Congratulations! completed Chapter 7 - Summary Tools. chapter, successfully summarized visualized environmental data, biodiversity counts, presence/absence data using various plotting techniques. ’d like explore Additional Resources based previous Spatial Data chapters, Raster Tools article also available.
code: events_matrix <- mauricie_birds_df %>%   dplyr::select(SiteCode, survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, ObservationCount, latitude, longitude) %>%   distinct() %>%   sf::st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) events_matrix <- events_matrix %>%    group_by(SiteCode, geometry) %>%    mutate(point_id = cur_group_id()) %>%   ungroup() events_matrix <- events_matrix %>%   mutate(longitude = sf::st_coordinates(.)[,1],  # Extract longitude          latitude = sf::st_coordinates(.)[,2]) %>%  # Extract latitude   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%  # Drop geometry column   as.data.frame() %>%   dplyr::select(point_id, SiteCode, survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, longitude, latitude)  # Keep relevant columns enviro_events_matrix <- left_join(events_matrix, enviro_data_df, by = "point_id") search_species("Golden-crowned Kinglet") #species_id = 14960 #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name english_name           french_name               taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>           <chr>                  <chr>                     <chr>       #> 1      14960 Regulus satrapa Golden-crowned Kinglet Roitelet à couronne dorée BIRDS  kinglet_events <- mauricie_birds_df %>%   filter(species_id == "14960")  kinglet_events <- left_join(enviro_events_matrix, kinglet_events,                           by = c("SiteCode",                                "survey_year",                                "survey_month",                                "survey_day",                                "latitude",                                "longitude")) kinglet_zero_fill <- kinglet_events %>%    mutate(ObservationCount = replace(ObservationCount, is.na(ObservationCount), 0)) %>% dplyr::select(point_id, SiteCode, survey_day, survey_month, survey_year, latitude, longitude, elevation:n_individuals, ObservationCount) kinglet_presence_absence <- kinglet_zero_fill %>%   mutate(Presence = ifelse(ObservationCount > 0, 1, 0))  # 1 = Presence, 0 = Absence kinglet_PA_summary_year <- kinglet_presence_absence %>%   group_by(survey_year, category = ifelse(ObservationCount > 0, "Presence", "Absence")) %>%   summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(kinglet_PA_summary_year, aes(x = as.factor(survey_year), y = count, fill = category)) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Presence" = "darkgreen", "Absence" = "lightgray")) +   labs(title = "Golden-crowned Kinglet Presence/Absence per Survey Year",        x = "Survey Year",        y = "Number of Observations") +   theme_minimal() ggplot(kinglet_presence_absence, aes(x = factor(Presence), y = ndvi, fill = factor(Presence))) +   geom_boxplot() +   labs(x = "Presence/Absence", y = "NDVI") +   ggtitle("Distribution of NDVI by Presence/Absence") +   theme_classic() # Reshape data for plotting multiple covariates kinglet_presence_absence_long <- pivot_longer(kinglet_presence_absence, cols = c("elevation", "ed", "pland_needleleaf", "pland_broadleaf", "pland_shrubland", "ndvi"),  names_to = "Covariate", values_to = "Value")  # Create box plots for all covariates ggplot(kinglet_presence_absence_long, aes(x = factor(Presence), y = Value, fill = factor(Presence))) +   geom_boxplot() +   facet_wrap(~ Covariate, scales = "free_y") +   labs(x = "Presence/Absence", y = "Covariate Value") +   ggtitle("Distribution of Covariates by Presence/Absence") +   theme(legend.position = "none")+   theme_classic() # Fit logistic regression model model <- glm(Presence ~ ed + elevation + ndvi + pland_broadleaf + pland_needleleaf + pland_shrubland,             data = kinglet_presence_absence, family = binomial)  # Create sequence for covariate values covar_range <- seq(min(kinglet_presence_absence$ed), max(kinglet_presence_absence$ed), length = 100)  # Generate predictions while holding other covariates at mean values newdata <- data.frame(   ed = covar_range,   elevation = mean(kinglet_presence_absence$elevation),   ndvi = mean(kinglet_presence_absence$ndvi),   pland_broadleaf = mean(kinglet_presence_absence$pland_broadleaf),    pland_needleleaf = mean(kinglet_presence_absence$pland_needleleaf),    pland_shrubland = mean(kinglet_presence_absence$pland_shrubland) )  pred_probs <- predict(model, newdata, type = "response")  # Plot response curve plot(covar_range, pred_probs, type = "l",       xlab = "Edge Denisty", ylab = "Probability of Kinglet Presence",      main = "Response Curve for Edge Density")

title: Chapter 1 - Zero-filling
text: observers collecting point count data field, recording birds see hear. recording birds see hear. NatureCounts data set therefore often lack zeros species detected survey. Zero-filling assigns count zero species detected observation period (ObservationCount = 0). Zeros can indicate two things - true absence species failure detect species. important considerations keep mind applying zero-filling methods: Biological Relevance: Ensure zeros adding accurately reflect true absences rather just missing data. distinction crucial valid interpretations. Sampling Bias: Consider potential biases sampling methods. certain areas times -sampled, zero-filling may misrepresent actual distribution abundance species. Data Structure: Understand structure dataset. Zero-filling may appropriate certain types data (e.g., count data) others (e.g., presence-data). Statistical Methods: Choose appropriate statistical methods can handle zero-inflated data. models specifically designed datasets many zeros, others may suitable. Impact Analysis: Assess zero-filling affect analysis outcomes. Adding zeros can influence mean values, variances, statistical metrics, potentially leading misleading conclusions. Documentation: Clearly document zero-filling process, including rationale chosen method assumptions made. transparency essential reproducibility others understand analysis. Contextual Factors: Take account environmental temporal factors may influence species presence absence. factors can help inform whether zeros appropriate specific contexts. carefully considering factors, can make informed decisions zero-filling implications dataset subsequent analyses. Good candidates zero-filling species reported consistently many sites within ranges. considered “many sites” depends species. Species rarely detected considered outside range likely poor candidates zero-filling. Note: Zero-filling, across methods, assumes least one species detected survey point. assumption nearly always true.

title: Chapter 1 - Zero-filling
text: format_zero_fill() function can help us infer species absence species detected sampling event, provided species reported event (.e. AllSpeciesReported “Yes”). Otherwise, function return error invalid records. dataset produces error, need filter data SamplingEventIdentifiers species recorded. Browse collections find Breeding Bird Surveys (BBS; 50 stops, Canada) dataset. Let’s bring list common names append dataframe easier interpretation. Read BBS data NatureCounts 2015 2020 province Saskatchewan example data set. want zero-fill dataframe, need download full collection given time period geography interest. just data species interest. ensure sampling events correctly identified zero-filling. Append english name BBS dataframe ensure ObservationCount numeric. Determine species reported dataset. Yes! , case, need filter dataset species recorded sampling event. Let’s apply format_zero_fill() function. Optionally, can specify columns retain output dataframe using extra_event /extra_species arguments. default, function zero fills SamplingEventIdentifier. However, argument may also used specify data zero-filled .e. SamplingEventIdentifer, SurveyAreaIdentifier, SiteCode, utm_square, etc. useful want determine whether species /observed particular zone! format_zero_fill() adds 0’s ObservationCount column default, can specify columns zero fill. example, create Presence/Absence data zero-filling custom column. First, select relevant columns original dataframe create presence column based ObservationCount. Zero-fill data specifying presence column fill argument. also converts presence column logical numeric.
code: collections <- meta_collections() View(meta_collections()) sp.list <- search_species() sp.list <- sp.list %>% dplyr::select(species_id, english_name) bbs50_can <- nc_data_dl(collections = "BBS50-CAN", years=c(2015,2020), region=list(statprov="SK"), username = "testuser", info = "zero fill example") bbs50_can <- bbs50_can %>% left_join(sp.list, by = "species_id") bbs50_can$ObservationCount <- as.numeric(bbs50_can$ObservationCount) count(bbs50_can, AllSpeciesReported) #>   AllSpeciesReported     n #> 1                Yes 80385 bbs50_can_zero_fill <- format_zero_fill(bbs50_can,                                   by = "SamplingEventIdentifier",                                  extra_event = c("latitude", "longitude"),                                  extra_species = "english_name") bbs50_can_presence <- bbs50_can %>%   dplyr::select(AllSpeciesReported, SamplingEventIdentifier, species_id, ObservationCount, latitude, longitude, english_name) %>%   mutate(presence = if_else(as.numeric(ObservationCount) > 0, TRUE, FALSE)) bbs50_can_pres_filled <- format_zero_fill(bbs50_can_presence,                                            fill = "presence",                                           by = "SamplingEventIdentifier",                                           extra_event = c("latitude", "longitude"),                                            extra_species = "english_name") #>  - Converted 'fill' column (presence) from logical to numeric

code: sp_ids <- unique(bbs50_can$species_id) # sp_ids <- c(19160, 19170, 19180) # Chestnut-collared Longspur, Upland Sandpiper, Western Meadowlark zero_filled_data <- list()  # Loop through each sp_ids for (i in sp_ids) {   # Filter the BBS data for each species in a given loop   all_species_data <- bbs50_can %>%      filter(species_id == i)      # Join the NatureCounts data with the events matrix   all_species_events <- left_join(events_matrix, all_species_data,                                   by = c("SiteCode",                                           "survey_year",                                           "survey_month",                                          "survey_day",                                           "latitude",                                           "longitude"))      # Zero-fill the `ObservationCount` column for each species and across all events   all_species_events <- all_species_events %>%     mutate(ObservationCount = replace(ObservationCount, is.na(ObservationCount), 0))      # Add the result to the list with species_id as the key   zero_filled_data[[as.character(i)]] <- all_species_events } zero_filled_dataframe <- bind_rows(zero_filled_data, .id = "species_id")

code: atlas_square_summ_on <- nc_query_table(table = "AtlasSquareSummary", username = "testuser",                                        statprov_code = "ON") # filter data for Ontario bmde_fbd_query <- nc_query_table(table = "bmde_filter_bad_dates", username = "testuser", project_id = "1013") rnest_query <- filter(rnest, speciesID %in% c(15770, 47674)) # filter for the American Robin and Common Gull

title: Chapter 2 - Auxiliary Tables
text: rNest R package enables backcalculation nest chronologies nest observations. helps describe nesting phenology based nest records held BirdsCanada database. development package aims produce robust description bird nesting phenology 311 bird species across Canada. See report . Initiation date - estimated date first egg laid nest attempt. Fledging date - estimated date first nestling leaves nest, nest attempt. Let’s examine rNest query performed American Robin Common Gull last step. initiation fledging dates use Julian date format. can convert dates day, month, time--day event, respectively. Ensure column numeric format. Create arbitrary base date, assuming event dates leap year. Create two new date columns converting Julian dates standard format. Extract fractional Julian dates convert time. Extract month day using month() day() functions lubridate package.
code: rnest_query <- rnest_query %>%   mutate(across(c(initiation, fledging), as.numeric)) base_date <- as.Date("2025-01-01") rnest_query <- rnest_query %>%   mutate(     initiation_date = base_date + initiation - 1,     fledging_date = base_date + fledging - 1   ) rnest_query <- rnest_query %>%   mutate(     initiation_time = hours(round((initiation - floor(initiation)) * 24)),     fledging_time = hours(round((fledging - floor(fledging)) * 24))   ) rnest_query <- rnest_query %>%   mutate(     initiation_month = month(initiation_date),     initiation_day = day(initiation_date),     fledging_month = month(fledging_date),     fledging_day = day(fledging_date)   ) %>%   dplyr::select(     speciesID,     speciesEnglish,     speciesFrench,     initiation,     initiation_month,     initiation_day,     initiation_time,     fledging,     fledging_month,     fledging_day,     fledging_time,     districtID,     districtNameEn   )

title: Chapter 2 - Auxiliary Tables
text: help represent rNest data visually, ’ll incorporate spatial data National Ecological Framework Canada available . -depth examples manipulating NatureCounts spatial data, see NatureCounts_SpatialData_Tutorial series. rNest data contains districtID field, refers ecodistrict observation event took place. ecodistrict subdivision ecoregion characterized distinctive assemblages relief, landforms, geology, soil, vegetation, water bodies fauna. Ecodistricts spatial data available series pre-packaged GeoJSON files subdirectory. interested base layer GeoJSON file, displayed raw text format URL. Read Ecodistricts layer URL using st_read() function. Rename districtID field rnest_query dataframe match one ecodistricts layer. Combine rnest_query data ecodistricts data new dataframe called rnest_join.
code: # Copy-paste the URL to the Ecodistricts base-layer geojson_url <- "https://agriculture.canada.ca/atlas/data_donnees/nationalEcologicalFramework/data_donnees/geoJSON/ed/nef_ca_ter_ecodistrict_v2_2.geojson"  # Read the GeoJSON file directly from the URL ecodistricts <- st_read(geojson_url) #> Reading layer `nef_ca_ter_ecodistrict_v2_2' from data source  #>   `https://agriculture.canada.ca/atlas/data_donnees/nationalEcologicalFramework/data_donnees/geoJSON/ed/nef_ca_ter_ecodistrict_v2_2.geojson'  #>   using driver `GeoJSON' #> Simple feature collection with 1025 features and 7 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -140.9994 ymin: 41.67355 xmax: -52.36457 ymax: 83.63317 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84  # Inspect the data print(ecodistricts) #> Simple feature collection with 1025 features and 7 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -140.9994 ymin: 41.67355 xmax: -52.36457 ymax: 83.63317 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>    OBJECTID ECODISTRICT_ID ECOREGION_ID ECOZONE_ID ECOPROVINCE_ID SHAPE_Length  SHAPE_Area                       geometry #> 1         1            139           33          3            3.1    1607587.8 75412497241 POLYGON ((-132.2716 69.7853... #> 2         2            134           32          3            3.1    1563994.4 62401339357 POLYGON ((-136.9713 69.3404... #> 3         3            135           32          3            3.1     165084.9  1966035838 POLYGON ((-139.1093 69.6522... #> 4         4            856          165         11           11.1    1141040.5 45812538986 POLYGON ((-139.8334 69.5159... #> 5         5            863          167         11           11.2    1523135.0 42356398185 POLYGON ((-140.9974 68.1527... #> 6         6            209           53          4            4.2     568436.5  2633988287 POLYGON ((-133.8711 67.5002... #> 7         7            212           53          4            4.2    1018745.7 14794658824 POLYGON ((-133.7398 67.4543... #> 8         8            213           53          4            4.2    1062059.6 35095791510 POLYGON ((-130.1416 66.8694... #> 9         9            866          168         11           11.3    1154925.7 64356636287 POLYGON ((-136.2435 65.7265... #> 10       10            897          175         12           12.2    2001852.3 97480332759 POLYGON ((-136.6212 63.1381... rnest_query <- rnest_query %>%   rename(ECODISTRICT_ID = districtID) rnest_join <- rnest_query %>%   inner_join(ecodistricts, by = "ECODISTRICT_ID")

title: Chapter 2 - Auxiliary Tables
text: Filter American Robin (speciesID = 15770) Calculate mean fledge age fledglings initiation month, respectively, create boxplot.  mean fledge age American Robin appears decrease subsequent initiation month.
code: rnest_robin <- rnest_join %>% filter(speciesID == 15770) # Calculate fledge age  rnest_robin <- rnest_robin %>%   mutate(     fledge_age = as.numeric(fledging - initiation)   )  # Plot fledge age (days) by initiation month ggplot(rnest_robin, aes(x = factor(initiation_month), y = fledge_age)) +   geom_boxplot(fill = "orange", color = "black") +   scale_x_discrete(labels = c("3" = "March", "4" = "April", "5" = "May", "6" = "June")) +   labs(x = "Initiation Month", y = "Fledge Age (Days)",         title = "Mean Fledge Age of the American Robin by Initiation Month") +   theme_minimal()

title: Chapter 2 - Auxiliary Tables
text: Let’s visualize potential nesting patterns using combined rNest ecodistricts dataset. can start mapping ecodistricts compare fledging dates American Robin. Convert rnest_join dataframe sf object using existing ‘geometry’ column Assign Coordinate Reference System (CRS) like EPSG:4326 (WGS84) combined data. Use ggplot() visualize Ecodistricts using color ramp represents fledging date.  Congratulations! completed Chapter 2: Auxiliary Tables. , accessed NatureCounts auxiliary tables using nc_query_tables function. also created basic data summaries maps using rNest ecodistricts data.
code: rnest_robin <- st_sf(rnest_robin) rnest_robin <- st_transform(rnest_robin, crs = 4326) # Plot ecodistricts with fledging date color ramp ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = rnest_robin, fill = "grey80", color = "white", size = 0.3) +  # Base ecodistrict map   geom_sf(data = rnest_robin, aes(fill = fledging), color = "black", size = 0.2) +    scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", name = "Fledging Date") +  # Color ramp for fledging date   labs(title = "Fledging Dates (Julian) by Ecodistrict for the American Robin",        caption = "Source: rNest and National Ecological Framework for Canada") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "right")

title: Data Access
text: downloads naturecounts require free NatureCounts account (sign ). data hosted NatureCounts immediately available users. Different data sets different access levels (also called akn_levels). full description different levels available NatureCounts site. Briefly, five levels R package naturecounts can potentially access three levels (users). Data access level 5 considered public data available users. Data access levels 4 3 private/semi-public projects/collections. access data must request access (see Requesting Access, ). Data access level 2 visible counts returned nc_count() metadata returned meta_collections() , etc., downloadable nc_data_dl() naturecounts R package without special permissions. Data access level 1 visible naturecounts R package without special permissions.

title: Data Access
text: can request access full partial datasets levels 3 4 NatureCounts data request page. request partial access, choose filters walk steps. request full access, choose collection check “Full access?” box Step 2. request submitted approved appropriate data custodian.

title: Data Access
text: Data full access can directly downloaded via nc_data_dl() function. Note request_ids created web requests () also created api requests: data downloaded via nc_data_dl() function request_id provided. following examples use “testuser” user available . can quickly sign free account access play around examples. Simply replace testuser username. example, previous download created api request_id. see request_ids created R package, use argument type = "api" nc_requests(). data can re-downloaded (quickly) using stored request_id.
code: bittern <- nc_data_dl(species = 2490, username = "sample", info = "nc_example") nc_requests(username = "testuser", type = "api")[1,] ##   request_id request_origin request_label  collection   status nrecords ## 1     155885            api   API Request RCBIOTABASE approved        2 ##                                      filter ## 1 project ('RCBIOTABASE'); species (133990) old <- nc_data_dl(request_id = 185663, username = "testuser")

title: Filtering data after download
text: Packages Downloading data directly Data Frame Downloading data SQLite DataBase (chickadee.nc) , starting new session existing SQLite database, first create connection database using database, can choose collect() data data frame (case identical chickadee_df, database large, faster leave database long possible. also use helper function add columns date doy (day year) data. data frames, directly modify data frame object. databases, ’ll modify connection, update table reference. Note: results -disk additions SQLite database. wish make add fields SQLite database, collect() data data frame first. dates can created survey_year, survey_month survey_day missing. Unless stated otherwise, following examples, demonstrate code works data frames databases.
code: library(naturecounts) library(dplyr) library(lubridate) boreal_chickadee_df <- nc_data_dl(species = 14320, collection = "BBS", verbose = FALSE,                                   username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") con <- nc_data_dl(species = 14320, collection = "BBS", sql_db = "boreal_chickadee",                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") con <- DBI::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), dbname = "boreal_chickadee.nc") boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") boreal_chickadee_df <- collect(boreal_chickadee_db) boreal_chickadee_df <- format_dates(boreal_chickadee_df, overwrite = TRUE) con <- format_dates(con) boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") filter(boreal_chickadee_df, is.na(date)) |>   select(survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, date) ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   survey_year survey_month survey_day date   ##         <int>        <int>      <int> <date> ## 1        2001           NA         NA NA     ## 2        2007           NA         NA NA     ## 3        2007           NA         NA NA     ## 4        1987           NA         NA NA

title: Zero-filling data
text: zero-filling requires species reported (can know species observed, wasn’t reported?), format_zero_fill return error records valid. Therefore, first thing need limit data SamplingEventIdentifiers species recorded. Note AllSpeciesReported may always strictly true, bird identification events (e.g., Christmas Bird Counts) may report bird species, probably report mammalian species, plants, etc. vice versa. Now can fill species missing sampling events.  might helpful use common names, process zero-filling, extra columns removed.
code: rc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc) ## Error: Column 'AllSpeciesReported' must be present and 'Yes' rc_all_species <- filter(rc, AllSpeciesReported == "Yes") count(rc_all_species, AllSpeciesReported) ##   AllSpeciesReported   n ## 1                Yes 173 rc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_all_species) ##  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric head(rc_filled) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id ObservationCount ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252456                1 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252491                0 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252494                0 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252456                2 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252491                0 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252494                0 ggplot(data = rc_filled, aes(x = factor(species_id), fill = ObservationCount > 0)) +   geom_bar(position = "dodge") +   labs(title = "Number of sampling events the species was observed")

title: Zero-filling data
text: keep columns associated species id, specify extra_species argument. keep columns associated sampling event, specify , addition sampling event id, argument. default, SamplingEventIdentifier used identify specific sampling events.

Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric head(rc_filled) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id ObservationCount        CommonName ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252456                1           Monarch ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252491                0       Red Admiral ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252494                0 Black Swallowtail ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252456                2           Monarch ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252491                0       Red Admiral ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252494                0 Black Swallowtail ##      ScientificName latitude longitude ## 1  Danaus plexippus  45.5111 -77.50533 ## 2  Vanessa atalanta  45.5111 -77.50533 ## 3 Papilio polyxenes  45.5111 -77.50533 ## 4  Danaus plexippus  45.5111 -77.50533 ## 5  Vanessa atalanta  45.5111 -77.50533 ## 6 Papilio polyxenes  45.5111 -77.50533

title: Zero-filling data
text: Sampling events aren’t way zero-filling data. Perhaps ’re interested whether species /observed particular location. message summarizing multiple observations means multiple observations per utm_square. example isn’t large enough slowed much, larger examples, can much faster simplify dataset first. Now zero-fill data set, get zero-filled, aggregated dataset.
code: rc_loc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_all_species,                                    by = "utm_square") ##  - Consider summarizing multiple observations per set of 'by' before zero-filling to increase speed ##  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric head(rc_loc_filled) ##   utm_square species_id ObservationCount ## 1    18TTR94     252456                1 ## 2    18TTR94     252491                0 ## 3    18TTR94     252494                0 ## 4    18TUR04     252456                1 ## 5    18TUR04     252456                1 ## 6    18TUR04     252456                1 rc_sum <- rc_all_species |>   group_by(utm_square, species_id, AllSpeciesReported) |>   summarize(ObservationCount = sum(as.numeric(ObservationCount), na.rm = TRUE),             .groups = "drop") head(rc_sum) ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   utm_square species_id AllSpeciesReported ObservationCount ##   <chr>           <int> <chr>                         <dbl> ## 1 18TTR94        252456 Yes                               1 ## 2 18TUR04        252456 Yes                              67 ## 3 18TUR04        252491 Yes                              46 ## 4 18TUR04        252494 Yes                              22 ## 5 18TUR17        252456 Yes                               1 ## 6 18TUR27        252491 Yes                               1 rc_sum_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_sum, by = "utm_square") head(rc_sum_filled) ##   utm_square species_id ObservationCount ## 1    18TTR94     252456                1 ## 2    18TTR94     252491                0 ## 3    18TTR94     252494                0 ## 4    18TUR04     252456               67 ## 5    18TUR04     252491               46 ## 6    18TUR04     252494               22

title: Zero-filling data
text: default format_zero_fill() adds 0’s ObservationCount column, can specify column zero fill. example, wanted deal Presence/Absence create new presence column zero-fill column.
code: rc_presence <- rc_all_species |>   select(species_id, AllSpeciesReported, ObservationCount, SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   mutate(presence = if_else(as.numeric(ObservationCount) > 0, TRUE, FALSE)) head(rc_presence) ##   species_id AllSpeciesReported ObservationCount SamplingEventIdentifier ## 1     252456                Yes                6      RCBIOTABASE-5553-1 ## 2     252491                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-5553-1 ## 3     252456                Yes                2      RCBIOTABASE-5547-1 ## 4     252456                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-5546-1 ## 5     252494                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-6235-1 ## 6     252491                Yes                3      RCBIOTABASE-5545-1 ##   presence ## 1     TRUE ## 2     TRUE ## 3     TRUE ## 4     TRUE ## 5     TRUE ## 6     TRUE rc_presence_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_presence, fill = "presence") ##  - Converted 'fill' column (presence) from logical to numeric head(rc_presence_filled) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id presence ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252456        1 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252491        0 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252494        0 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252456        1 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252491        0 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252494        0

title: Mapping Observations
text: ’re going take quick look spatial distribution using ggplot2 ggspatial get basemaps. First let’s get idea many distinct points (often multiple observations recorded location). 1263 sites 7211 observations. Next let’s convert data spatial data can plot spatially (.e. make map!). Note ’re using CRS EPSG code 4326 ’s reflects unprojected, GPS data lat/lon. First omit NAs sf data frames missing locations. Now ’re ready make map distribution observations. ’ll use baselayer OpenStreetMap add observations.  Let’s count observations site.

title: Mapping Observations
text: want get fancy can also create interactive maps using mapview packages (see also leaflet R package).
code: mapview(house_finches_sf, zcol = "survey_year", at = seq(1965, 2005, by = 10),         map.types = "Esri.WorldImagery")

title: Mapping Observations
text: complex, detailed maps, can use variety spatial data files layer data maps area. ’ll get outlines Canada ’s Provinces Territories rnaturalearth.  Let’s add observations (note data transformed match projection first layer, canada data).  can also focus Alberta  Perhaps see observations distributed among Alberta’s Bird Conservation Regions (BCRs). First ’ll grab BCR shape file Birds Canada1. ’ll download zip file extracted folder easier work . Note spatial data GDB format, ’re working folder named XXX.gdb. Add layer plot.  border cases bit hard separate visually. solve problem, can merge observations BCRs plot observations BCR well. First ’ll transform observation data match CRS bcr, ’ll join BCR information observations, based whether observations overlap BCR polygon (default left join). Now BCR designation observation. border cases now resolved.  might also interested observations time. First ’ll bin yearly observations ’ll also want see many sample years per decade. Now can see House Finch observations change years
code: canada <- ne_states(country = "canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) ab <- filter(canada, name == "Alberta")  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) download.file("https://services1.arcgis.com/d5M16PKlQTMEVyua/arcgis/rest/services/BCR_terrestrial_master/FeatureServer/replicafilescache/BCR_terrestrial_master_-8688020410858769740.zip", "BCR_terrestrial_master.zip") unzip("BCR_terrestrial_master.zip", junkpaths = TRUE, exdir = "BCR_terrestrial_master.gdb") bcr <- st_read("BCR_terrestrial_master.gdb") |>   st_transform(3347) |>   st_intersection(ab) ## Reading layer `BCR_Terrestrial_Master' from data source  ##   `/home/runner/work/naturecounts/naturecounts/vignettes/articles/BCR_terrestrial_master.gdb'  ##   using driver `OpenFileGDB' ## Warning in CPL_read_ogr(dsn, layer, query, as.character(options), quiet, : GDAL ## Message 1: organizePolygons() received a polygon with more than 100 parts.  The ## processing may be really slow.  You can skip the processing by setting ## METHOD=SKIP. ## Simple feature collection with 4414 features and 8 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -6653676 ymin: -2736345 xmax: 2978061 ymax: 5253189 ## Projected CRS: North_America_Lambert_Conformal_Conic ## Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout ## all geometries ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(bcr_label)), alpha = 0.5, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") house_finches_sf <- house_finches_sf |>   st_transform(st_crs(bcr)) |>   st_join(bcr) ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(bcr_label)), alpha = 0.25, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, aes(fill = factor(bcr_label)), shape = 21) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") house_finches_sf <- mutate(house_finches_sf,                             years = cut(survey_year,                                         breaks = seq(1960, 2010, 10),                                         labels = seq(1960, 2000, 10), right = FALSE)) years <- house_finches_sf |>   group_by(years) |>   summarize(n = length(unique(survey_year)), .groups = "drop") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(bcr_label)), alpha = 0.5, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") +   geom_sf_text(data = years, x = 4427134, y = 2965275, hjust = 0, vjust = 1,                 aes(label = paste0("n = ", n))) +   facet_wrap(~years)

title: Mapping Observations
text: can also use naturecounts helper functions create presence/absence maps. download data RCBIOTABASE collection, make sure keep observations species location reported, create new presence column either TRUE, FALSE, NA sampling event. Finally use format_zero_fill() function fill sampling events cardinals (species_id 19360) detected (presence 0). bit convoluted, ’ll grab coordinates Sampling Event. necessary errors (worth reporting!) one lat/lon combo sampling event. Now presence/absence data cardinals, can create map.
code: cardinals <- nc_data_dl(collection = "RCBIOTABASE", username = "testuser",                          info = "nc_tutorial") ## Using filters: collections (RCBIOTABASE); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min) ## Collecting available records... ##    collection nrecords ## 1 RCBIOTABASE    13055 ## Total records: 13,055 ##  ## Downloading records for each collection: ##   RCBIOTABASE ##     Records 1 to 5000 / 13055 ##     Records 5001 to 10000 / 13055 ##     Records 10001 to 13055 / 13055 cardinals_zf <- cardinals |>   filter(AllSpeciesReported == "Yes", !is.na(latitude), !is.na(longitude)) |>   group_by(species_id, AllSpeciesReported, SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   summarize(presence = sum(as.numeric(ObservationCount)) > 0, .groups = "drop") |>   format_zero_fill(species = 19360, by = "SamplingEventIdentifier",                    fill = "presence") ##  - Converted 'fill' column (presence) from logical to numeric coords <- cardinals |>   select("SamplingEventIdentifier", "latitude", "longitude") |>   group_by(SamplingEventIdentifier, latitude, longitude) |>   mutate(n = n()) |>  # Count number of unique coordinates   group_by(SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   slice_max(n, with_ties = FALSE) |> # Grab the most common coordinates for each event   select(-"n")  cardinals_zf <- left_join(cardinals_zf, coords, by = "SamplingEventIdentifier")  head(cardinals_zf) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id presence latitude longitude ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10000-1      19360        0 45.58604 -77.48721 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10001-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10002-1      19360        0 45.50803 -77.50786 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10003-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10004-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10005-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 cnt <- st_as_sf(cardinals_zf, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   group_by(presence) |>   count(geometry)  ggplot() +   annotation_map_tile(type = "osm", zoomin = 0) +   geom_sf(data = cnt, aes(size = n, colour = factor(presence)), alpha = 0.5) +   scale_colour_manual(name = "Presence/Absence", values = c("#31688E", "#440154"),                        labels = c("1" = "Present", "0" = "Absent")) +   scale_size_continuous(name = "Number of Sampling Events", range = c(1, 20)) +   labs(caption = "Copyright OpenStreetMap contributors",        title = "Presence/Absence of Cardinals in the RCBIOTABASE collection") ## Zoom: 9 ## Fetching 16 missing tiles ##   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |  |                                                                              |=======================================                               |  56%  | |================================================                      |  69%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75%  |                                                                              |=========================================================             |  81%  |                                                                              |=============================================================         |  88%  | |======================================================================| 100% ## ...complete!

title: Exploring IBAs and BCRs
text: get visual idea different Important Bird Areas , let’s plot map Canada. First need grab IBA data frame convert spatial object. data contains lat/lon, assign CRS 4326 GPS lat/lon data, convert match crs maps.  want narrow one province, filter IBA data frame get limits Northwest Territories Put together  detailed view IBAs, can also grab shape files Birds Canada.  really explore areas, interactive maps can really useful. Note can move map, zoom , click specific IBAs information.
code: iba <- meta_iba_codes() |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = iba) iba_nwt <- filter(iba, statprov == "NT") limits <- st_bbox(filter(canada, name == "Northwest Territories")) ggplot() +    theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = iba_nwt) +   geom_sf_text(data = iba_nwt, aes(label = iba_site), size = 3, vjust = -0.5) +   coord_sf(xlim = limits[c("xmin", "xmax")], ylim = limits[c("ymin", "ymax")]) iba <- st_read("https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:iba&outputFormat=application%2Fjson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `OGRGeoJSON' from data source  ##   `https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:iba&outputFormat=application%2Fjson'  ##   using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 619 features and 7 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -141.2376 ymin: 41.67177 xmax: -52.66698 ymax: 78.10591 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 iba <- filter(iba, Status == "confirmed") # Omit historical areas  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada, colour = "grey80") +   geom_sf(data = iba, fill = "blue", colour = NA, show.legend = FALSE, alpha = 0.5) mapview(iba)

title: Exploring IBAs and BCRs
text: Bird Conservation Regions also available Birds Canada.  , interactive maps can really useful.
code: bcr <- st_read("https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:bcr&outputFormat=application%2Fjson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `OGRGeoJSON' from data source  ##   `https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:bcr&outputFormat=application%2Fjson'  ##   using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 66 features and 3 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -179.1335 ymin: 14.54426 xmax: -52.54375 ymax: 83.14808 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = na, colour = "grey80") +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = bcr), show.legend = FALSE, alpha = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_c() mapview(bcr)

title: Region Codes
text: region must named list one following: country - Country code (e.g., CA Canada) statprov - State/province code (e.g., MB Manitoba) subnational2 - Subnational (type 2) code (e.g., CA.MB.07 Brandon Area) iba - Important Bird Areas (IBA) code (e.g., AB001 Beaverhill Lake Alberta) bcr - Bird Conservation Regions (e.g., 2 Western Alaska) utm_squares - UTM square code (e.g., 10UFE96 grid Alberta) bbox - Bounding box coordinates (e.g., c(left = -101.097223, bottom = 50.494717, right = -99.511239, top = 51.027557) box containing Riding Mountain National Park Manitoba) use region argument:
code: nc_count(region = list(statprov = "NB")) ## Without a username, using 'show = "all"' ## Using filters: statprov (NB) ## # A tibble: 84 × 4 ##    collection    akn_level access     nrecords ##    <chr>             <int> <chr>         <int> ##  1 ATOWLS                4 by request    16001 ##  2 BBS                   5 full          54578 ##  3 BBS50-CAN             5 full         207572 ##  4 CBC                   2 no access     21559 ##  5 EBIRD-CA-AT           4 by request  2583049 ##  6 EBIRD-CA-SENS         3 by request       96 ##  7 EBUTTERFLY            5 full           2393 ##  8 GBBC                  4 by request    12215 ##  9 GBIF_02DD359E         5 full            470 ## 10 GBIF_040C5662         5 full             43 ## # ℹ 74 more rows

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: ’ll using tidyverse packages dplyr ggplot2 data manipulation plotting, respectively. ’ll use gridExtra combine figures. ’ll use sf package working spatial data, rnaturalearth package get example spatial data. spatial data files like read R, recommend reading Reading, Writing Converting Simple Features Vignette sf website. First ’ll get spatial objects explorations rnaturalearth package. map Canada map Ontario, transformed CRS 4326 (unprojected lat/lon) 3347 (NAD83 Statistics Canada).  Alternatively specify groups inside ggplot()
code: library(naturecounts) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth) na <- ne_countries(continent = "north america", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  canada <- ne_states(country = "canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  ontario <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Ontario") |>   st_transform(3347)  manitoba <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Manitoba") |>   st_transform(3347) ggplot() +    theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = canada) +                  # Map of Canada    geom_sf(data = ontario, fill = "orange")  # Map of Ontario ggplot() +    theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = canada, aes(fill = name == "Ontario"), show.legend = FALSE)+   scale_fill_manual(values = c("grey90", "orange"))

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: example, wanted collect public observations Winnipeg, Manitoba… Now ’ll get polygon representing Winnipeg, MB.  Looks like polygon Winnipeg doesn’t exactly match subnational2 area. ’s okay, ’ll filter match polygon:
code: search_region("winnipeg", type = "subnational2") ## # A tibble: 1 × 5 ##   country_code statprov_code subnational2_code subnational2_name                         ebird_code ##   <chr>        <chr>         <chr>             <chr>                                     <chr>      ## 1 CA           MB            CA.MB.11          Division No. 11 - Winnipeg Capital Region CA-MB-EL obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(subnational2 = "CA.MB.11"),                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") winnipeg <- st_read("https://data.winnipeg.ca/resource/2nyq-f444.geojson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `2nyq-f444' from data source `https://data.winnipeg.ca/resource/2nyq-f444.geojson' using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 1 field ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -97.34915 ymin: 49.71356 xmax: -96.95653 ymax: 49.99401 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 obs_sf <- st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = winnipeg) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf) obs_sf <- st_join(obs_sf, distinct(winnipeg), left = FALSE)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = winnipeg) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf)

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: following example, let’s assume wish concentrate observations urban areas Ontario, Canada. ’ll download data rnaturalearth package save working directory (“.”) Now ’ve saved , can load use. First ’ll transform 3347 CRS clip urban areas match borders Ontario (st_insection(spatial1, spatial2)). care geometry Ontario, data (st_geometry(ontario)).  Now filter observations urban areas, first step get UTM squares overlap areas. can collecting UTM squares meta_utm_squares() filtering include overlap urban areas.  ’s bit tricky see exactly ’s going , let’s zoom bit. However, ’s also bit tricky zoom ’re using non-lat/lon CRS units unintuitive. let’s specify limits want, transform CRS ’re using use set limits. convenience, ’ll use patchwork package combine figures side--side can get really good look ’re .  now can see utm_squares ’ve selected overlap urban areas. Now can download observations areas. can take time server process many utm_squares, ’ll increase timeout 5 minutes download couple utm squares. Finally, clip resulting observations exact urban areas:  However, sending large lists UTM squares can slow, consider using bounding box filtering downloaded data fact.
code: ne_download(scale = 10, type = "urban_areas", returnclass = "sf",              destdir = ".", load = FALSE) ## [1] "ne_10m_urban_areas" urban <- ne_load(scale = 10, type = "urban_areas", returnclass = "sf",                   destdir = ".") ## Reading layer `ne_10m_urban_areas' from data source  ##   `/tmp/RtmpLb0xoy/vignettes/region-spatial_files/ne_10m_urban_areas.shp' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 11878 features and 4 fields ## Geometry type: POLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -157.9912 ymin: -51.05304 xmax: 178.0338 ymax: 69.76986 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 urban_ontario <- urban |>   st_transform(3347) |>   st_intersection(st_geometry(ontario)) ## Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all geometries ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "orange") utm_on <- meta_utm_squares() |>   filter(statprov_code == "ON") |>   st_transform(3347) |>  # Transform to match urban CRS   st_filter(urban_ontario)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = utm_on, fill = "red") +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) zoom <- data.frame(lon = c(-81, -78, -81, -78),                    lat = c(43, 43, 45, 45)) |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("lon", "lat"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347) |>   st_bbox() zoom ##      xmin      ymin      xmax      ymax  ## 7067507.7  830951.5 7352759.4 1101349.9 g1 <- ggplot() +     theme_bw() +      geom_sf(data = ontario) +     geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +     coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])  g2 <- ggplot() +     theme_bw() +      geom_sf(data = ontario) +     geom_sf(data = utm_on, fill = "red", alpha = 0.5) +     geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +     coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])  g1 + g2 obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(utm_squares = utm_on$utm_square[1:10]),                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", timeout = 300,                    info = "nc_vignette") obs_sf <- st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(crs = 3347) |>   st_join(distinct(urban_ontario), left = FALSE)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf, size = 1) +   coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: example, ’ll gather observations around Jasper Alberta. First ’ll define area want grab. Jasper 52.8755, -118.0833, want get bout lat lon around . Now ’ll get background map Alberta. Let’s see looks like.  Now can give coordinates directly nc_data_dl() function. Let’s take look…
code: jasper <- st_bbox(c(xmin = -118.0833 - 0.5,                      xmax = -118.0833 + 0.5,                      ymin = 52.8755 - 0.5,                     ymax = 52.8755 + 0.5),                    crs = 4326) alberta <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Alberta") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = alberta) +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sfc(jasper), fill = "orange") obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(bbox = jasper), verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser",                    info = "nc_vignette") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sfc(jasper), fill = "orange") +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326))

title: Selecting columns and fields to download
text: several ways get information different field/columns sets. can get list different versions meta_bmde_versions() function. can get list specific fields/columns included version using meta_bmde_fields() function can see BMDE versions used different collections looking metadata associated collection.
code: meta_bmde_versions() ## # A tibble: 8 × 3 ##   descr                                           shorthand version             ##   <chr>                                           <chr>     <chr>               ## 1 BMDE 1.38                                       NA        BMDE1.38            ## 2 BMDE 2.0                                        core      BMDE2.00            ## 3 BMDE 2.0 (extended list)                        extended  BMDE2.00-ext        ## 4 BMDE 2.0 (minimum)                              minimum   BMDE2.00-min        ## 5 Banding extension to BMDE 2.0                   NA        BMDE-BAND-2.00      ## 6 Monarch Knowledge Network extension to BMDE 2.0 NA        BMDE-MKN-2.00       ## 7 Nest record extension to BMDE 2.0               NA        BMDE-NEST-2.00      ## 8 Nest record extension (visit data) to BMDE 2.0  NA        BMDE-NESTVISIT-2.00 meta_bmde_fields(version = "BMDE-BAND-2.00") |>   head() ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   field_order version        local_name             ##         <int> <chr>          <chr>                  ## 1           1 BMDE-BAND-2.00 GlobalUniqueIdentifier ## 2           2 BMDE-BAND-2.00 DateLastModified       ## 3           3 BMDE-BAND-2.00 BasisOfRecord          ## 4           4 BMDE-BAND-2.00 InstitutionCode        ## 5           5 BMDE-BAND-2.00 CollectionCode         ## 6           6 BMDE-BAND-2.00 CatalogNumber meta_collections() |>    head() ## # A tibble: 6 × 11 ##   bmdr_code  bmde_version project_id n_locations collection_name_fr   collection ##   <chr>      <chr>             <int>       <int> <chr>                <chr>      ## 1 ABATLAS1   BMDE2.00           1042        2209 Atlas des oiseaux n… ABATLAS1   ## 2 ABATLAS2   BMDE2.00           1042        5359 Atlas des oiseaux n… ABATLAS2   ## 3 ABBIRDRECS BMDE2.00           1042       21962 Observations d'oise… ABBIRDRECS ## 4 ABOWLS     BMDE2.00           1012         213 Inventaire des hibo… ABOWLS     ## 5 ACCWS      BMDE2.00           1062          16 NA                   ACCWS      ## 6 ATBANS     BMDE2.00           1074         132 NA                   ATBANS     ## # ℹ 5 more variables: min_year <int>, max_year <int>, collection_name <chr>, ## #   akn_level <int>, n_records <int>

title: Species codes
text: simplest way determine species id (way, non-avian taxa) use search_species() function searches species id according scientific, English French name returns data frame taxonomic information related hits: species ids can used download data either directly: saving referencing data frame: might considered overkill single species, useful want download data multiple species:
code: search_species("moose") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name english_name french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>           <chr>        <chr>       <chr>       #> 1     133990 Alces alces     Moose        NA          MAMMALS search_species("swallowtail") #> # A tibble: 8 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name     english_name            french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>               <chr>                   <chr>       <chr>       #> 1     252492 Battus philenor     Pipevine Swallowtail    Papillon d… BUTTERFL    #> 2     252493 Eurytides marcellus Zebra Swallowtail       Papillon z… BUTTERFL    #> 3     252494 Papilio polyxenes   Black Swallowtail       Papillon d… BUTTERFL    #> 4     252495 Papilio machaon     Old World Swallowtail   Machaon     BUTTERFL    #> 5     252496 Papilio cresphontes Giant Swallowtail       Grand port… BUTTERFL    #> 6     252497 Papilio glaucus     Eastern Tiger Swallowt… Papillon t… BUTTERFL    #> 7     252498 Papilio canadensis  Canadian Tiger Swallow… Papillon t… BUTTERFL    #> 8     252499 Papilio troilus     Spicebush Swallowtail   Papillon c… BUTTERFL search_species("mesange a tete noire") #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name                english_name french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>                          <chr>        <chr>       <chr>       #> 1      14280 Poecile atricapillus           Black-cappe… Mésange à … BIRDS       #> 2      40932 Poecile atricapillus x gambeli Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 3      44462 Poecile atricapillus x hudson… Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 4      44466 Poecile atricapillus x Baeolo… Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 5      45746 Poecile atricapillus/gambeli   Black-cappe… Mésange à … BIRDS moose <- nc_data_dl(species = 133990, verbose = FALSE,                      username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") moose_id <- search_species("moose")$species_id moose <- nc_data_dl(species = moose_id, verbose = FALSE,                      username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") chickadee_ids <- search_species("chickadee") chickadee_ids  # Let's take the first three chickadees <- nc_data_dl(species = chickadee_ids$species_id[1:3], verbose = FALSE,                           username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette")

title: Species codes
text: Taxonomy bird species long included various alphanumeric codes different taxonomic authorities. codes often include separate codes recognized subdivisions species (subspecies, subpopulations, hybrids, etc.). search_species_code() allows search avian species ids according authorities.

title: Species codes
text: default taxonomic authority used BSCDATA, uses 4-letter alpha codes: search function case insensitive: However, can search codes different authorities, specifying appropriate authority argument:
code: search_species_code("BCCH") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name      english_name           french_name     #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>           #> 1      14280 BCCH    Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête… search_species_code("bcch") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name      english_name           french_name     #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>           #> 1      14280 BCCH    Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête… search_species_code(8868, authority = "CBC") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id CBC   scientific_name      english_name           french_name       #>        <int> <chr> <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>             #> 1      14280 8868  Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête n…

title: Species codes
text: default, search_species_codes() returns species ids related search term. example, searching myrtle warblers (MYWA), one two subspecies yellow-rumped warbler (YRWA) returns subspecies parent species. Note: Different taxonomic authorities recognize different subgroups. example, BSCDATA recognizes 4 groups dark-eyed juncos: Whereas CBC also recognizes sub group hybrids (Guadalupe junco): can search one authority time. Note search term needs match one authority (), information returned reflects authorities combined.
code: search_species_code("MYWA") #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name             english_name        french_name #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                       <chr>               <chr>       #> 1      16610 YRWA    Setophaga coronata          Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… #> 2      16620 MYWA    Setophaga coronata coronata Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… #> 3      16630 AUWA    Setophaga coronata auduboni Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… search_species_code("DEJU") #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name                    english_name french_name #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                              <chr>        <chr>       #> 1      19090 SCJU    Junco hyemalis hyemalis/carolinen… Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #> 2      19110 PSJU    Junco hyemalis mearnsi             Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #> 3      42218 DEJU    Junco hyemalis                     Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #> 4      47928 ORJU    Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]    Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… search_species_code("12385", authority = "CBC") #> # A tibble: 11 × 5 #>    species_id CBC   scientific_name                     english_name french_name #>         <int> <chr> <chr>                               <chr>        <chr>       #>  1      42218 12385 Junco hyemalis                      Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  2      19090 12386 Junco hyemalis hyemalis/carolinens… Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  3      41434 12388 Junco hyemalis cismontanus          Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  4      19100 12389 Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]     Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  5      19110 12390 Junco hyemalis mearnsi              Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  6      42219 12391 Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group] x … Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  7      19112 12392 Junco hyemalis aikeni               Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  8      19111 12394 Junco hyemalis caniceps             Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #>  9      42220 12395 Junco hyemalis mearnsi x caniceps   Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #> 10      40859 12396 Junco hyemalis dorsalis             Dark-eyed J… Junco ardo… #> 11      39768 12398 Junco insularis                     Guadalupe J… Junco de G… search_species_code("DEJU", authority = c("BSCDATA", "CBC")) #> # title: Species codes
text: want subgroups, can use results = "exact" argument return exact match.
code: search_species_code("DEJU", results = "exact") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name english_name    french_name   #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>           <chr>           <chr>         #> 1      42218 DEJU    Junco hyemalis  Dark-eyed Junco Junco ardoisé search_species_code("ORJU", results = "exact") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name                 english_name    french_name #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                           <chr>           <chr>       #> 1      47928 ORJU    Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group] Dark-eyed Junc… Junco ardo…

title: Species codes
text: specific type search ’d like , may better using filter() function dplyr package. example, let’s assume ’re interested collecting species codes Muridae family. can get entire species list omitting search term, also return taxonomic information available show = "" argument. Now can search family lot muridae species! probably many actual database. can download available observations species, passing species_ids nc_data_dl() function. Actually expected (although many compared bird species).

title: Testing image creation
text: precompile script: script pre-compiles vignettes replaces figure paths appropriately. Note relies figures alt text least fig.cap = "" creates different style figure replacement therefore works. precompiled vignettes also need define figure path vignettes/articles/figures folder. Provide suffix well prevent duplicates.
code: # Pre-compile vignettes which run for a while library(knitr) library(readr) library(stringr)  # Remove the figures folder (start clean) unlink("figures", recursive = TRUE)  # Make sure to put figures in local dir in knitr chunk options v <- list.files("vignettes", ".orig$", full.names = TRUE, recursive = TRUE)  for(i in v) {   new <- stringr::str_remove(i, ".orig$")   knit(i, new)      read_lines(new) %>%     str_replace_all("\"vignettes(/articles)*/", "\"") %>%     write_lines(new) }  cache <- list.files("./vignettes", "cache", include.dirs = TRUE,                     recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE) unlink(cache, recursive = TRUE)  #build vignette #devtools::build_vignettes() #unlink("./doc/", recursive = TRUE) #unlink("./Meta/", recursive = TRUE) knitr::opts_chunk$set(   collapse = TRUE,   comment = "#>",   # For pre-compiling and pkgdown (relative to pkg home)   fig.path = "figures/suffix_",   dpi = 150 )

title: Testing image creation
text: Note: Must use fig.alt set fig.cap = ""
code: library(naturecounts) library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = bcch, aes(x = survey_year)) +    geom_bar()

title: Testing image creation
text: Put image vignettes/articles/figures_other folder Reference image working directory article. include_graphics() Use fig.alt = "Test birds canada logo", fig.cap = ""  Directly markdown: ![]() Note: Use \ end ensure text treated alt text caption (ref) ![Test birds canada logo](figures_other/logo.png)\
code: include_graphics("figures_other/logo.png")

what: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: Access download data plant animal populations various databases NatureCounts, service managed Birds Canada. See tutorials, documentation articles naturecounts package Website

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: can install main version naturecounts R-Universe
code: install.packages("naturecounts",                   repos = c(birdscanada = 'https://birdscanada.r-universe.dev',                            CRAN = 'https://cloud.r-project.org'))

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
code: library(naturecounts)

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: Use nc_count() function return collections number observations access (returns collections associated username sample). Use show = "" argument show counts collections available (public otherwise).
code: nc_count(username = "sample") #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   collection akn_level access nrecords #>   <chr>          <int> <chr>     <int> #> 1 SAMPLE1            0 full        991 #> 2 SAMPLE2            0 full        995 nc_count(show = "all") %>%   head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   collection akn_level access     nrecords #>   <chr>          <int> <chr>         <int> #> 1 ABATLAS1           5 full         123364 #> 2 ABATLAS2           5 full         201357 #> 3 ABBIRDRECS         5 full         357264 #> 4 ATBANS             3 by request      267 #> 5 ATOWLS             4 by request    33964 #> 6 BBS                5 full        5735895

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: Fetch observations bittern available user sample local data frame. First find species id Use id nc_data_dl(). info parameter short description data downloaded . Alternatively, save downloaded data SQLite database (bittern).

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: nc_count() nc_data_dl() variety arguments allow filter counts/data prior downloading. options include collections, species, years, doy (day--year), region, site_type (users can specify 3 ). nc_data_dl() additional arguments fields_set fields can customize fields/columns include download. See function examples (nc_count(), nc_data_dl()) following articles information filters: Collections Species Codes Regional Codes IBAs BCRs (regions) Using spatial data filter observations also article post-filtering data

what: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Common arguments nc_data_dl nc_count

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: collections Character vector. collection codes download data. NULL (default) downloads data available collections project_ids Character/Numeric vector. project ids download data. First collections associated project_id determined, data downloaded collection. collections project_ids supplied, combined. species Numeric vector. Numeric species ids (see details) years Numeric vector. start/end years data download. Can use NA either start end, single value return data single year. doy Character/Numeric vector. start/end day--year download (1-366 dates can converted day year). Can use NA either start end region List. Named list one following options: country, statprov, subnational2, iba, bcr, utm_squares, bbox. See details site_type Character vector. type site return (e.g., IBA). username Character vector. Username http://naturecounts.ca. provided, user prompted password. left NULL, public collections returned. info Character vector. Short description reason download. E.g., "COSEWIC report", "Impact Assessment Study", "School project", etc. kind information helps NatureCounts.ca justify utility database. Required unless resuming/re-downloaded request_id. request_id Numeric. Specific request id check download. timeout Numeric. Number seconds connecting server times . verbose Logical. Show messages?

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: public data available username/password (sign free NatureCounts account). However, access private/semi-public projects/collections must request access. See Access request_ids section information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Numeric species id codes can determined functions search_species() search_species_code(). See also article species codes information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: format day year (doy) fairly flexible can whole number 1 366 anything recognized lubridate-package's ymd() function. However, must order year, month, day. Note year ignored converting day year, except result 1 day offset leap years.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Regions defined codes reflecting country, state/province, subnational (level 2), Important Bird Areas (IBA), Bird Conservation Regions (BCR) (see search_region() codes). can also defined providing specific UTM squares download bounding box area specifies min/max longitude min/max latitude (bbox). See article regional filters information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: default data downloaded minimum set fields/columns. However, advanced applications, users may wish specify fields/columns return. Bird Monitoring Data Exchange (BMDE) schema keeps track variables used augment observation data. different versions reflecting different collections variables can specified download one four ways: fields_set can specific shorthand reflecting BMDE version: core, extended minimum (default). See meta_bmde_versions() see BMDE version shorthand refers . fields_set can default uses default BMDE version particular collection (note download one collection, field sets expand cover fields/columns combined collections) fields_set can exact BMDE version. See meta_bmde_versions() options. fields_set can custom fields argument can character vector specifying exact fields/columns return. See meta_bmde_fields()) potential fields values. Note cases set fields/columns always returned, matter fields_set used.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Access data collection either available "full" "request". Use nc_count(username = "USER", show = ""), see accessibility collections. "Full" access means data can immediately requested directly naturecounts R package. "request" means request must submitted online approved data can downloaded naturecounts. means two types data requests: ones made naturecounts R package (API requests) made online Web Request Form (Web requests). Every request (either method) generates request_id identifies filter set collections requested. Details requests can reviewed nc_requests() function. download data "full" access, users can either specify filters, repeating download, can use request_id nc_requests(). Otherwise, user "full" access, must supply approved request_id nc_data_dl() function (e.g., nc_data_dl(request_id = 152000, username = "USER")). Use nc_requests() see request_ids, filters, approval status. Requests "full" access additional collections can made online Web Request Form checking "Full access?" box Step 2 form.

what: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: COSEWIC Index Area Occupancy (IAO; also called Area Occupancy, AOO IUCN) Extent Occurrence (EOO; IUCN well) metrics used support status assessments potentially endangered species.

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
code: cosewic_ranges(   df_db,   record = "record_id",   coord_lon = "longitude",   coord_lat = "latitude",   species = "species_id",   iao_grid_size_km = 2,   eoo_p = 0.95,   filter_unique = FALSE,   spatial = TRUE )

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: df_db Either data frame connection database naturecounts table. record Character. Name column containing record identification. coord_lon Character. Name column containing longitude. coord_lat Character. Name column containing latitude. species Character. Name column containing species identification. iao_grid_size_km Numeric. Size grid (km) use calculating IAO. Default COSEWIC requirement (2). Use caution changing. eoo_p Numeric. percentile calculate convex hull . Defaults 0.95 95% convex hull ensure outlier points artificially inflate EOO. Note final COSEWIC report, may appropriate. Set 1 include points. filter_unique Logical. Whether filter observations unique locations. Use many data points work . changes nature observation , also may bias EOO calculations using less 100% points (see eoo_p). spatial Logical. Whether return sf spatial objects showing calculations. FALSE (default) returns data frame IAO EOO values. TRUE returns list objects values spatial grid/polygons.

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: Summarized data frame (ranges) list containing ranges, summarized data frame, spatial, list two spatial data frames. ranges contains columns n_records_total - Total number records used create ranges min_record - Minimum number records within IAO cells max_record - Maximum number records within IAO cells median_record - Median number records within IAO cells grid_size_km - IAO cell size (area squared) n_occupied - Number IAO cells least one record iao - IAO value (grid_size_km^2 * n_occupied) eoo_pXX - EOO area calculated convex hull percentile eoo_p (e.g., 95%) spatial contains spatial data frames iao_sf - Polygons IAO grids n_records per cell eoo_sf - Polygon Convex Hull percentile eoo_p

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: Note IUCN calls metric AOO, COSEWIC, AOO actually different measure, biological area occupancy. See Distribution section 'Instructions preparing COSEWIC status reports' details. default EOO calculated using inner 95% points (based distance centroid). ensure first-pass EOO reject species consideration outlier observations. However, final COSEWIC assessment report, likely better carefully explore data ensure outliers use full data set (.e. set eoo_p = 1). IAO calculated first assessing large grids (10x large specified size). smaller grids created within large grid cells containing observations. speeds process avoiding creation grids areas observations. means plots spatial objects may grids large areas lacking observations. See examples. Details IAO EOO calculated used COSEWIC - Guidelines use Index Area Occupancy COSEWIC Assessments COSEWIC - Instructions preparing COSEWIC status reports COSEWIC - Table 2 COSEWIC quantitative criteria guidelines status assessment Wildlife Species
